Dark-colored cordylines can tolerate bright light once acclimated, but if your cordyline is variegated with lighter colors, indirect light is best. A sunny eastern window or a few feet away from a southern or western window is best.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your cordyline when the top 25-50% of soil is dry. Water thoroughly, and be sure to empty the saucer of any excess water to prevent root rot. Never let this tropical plant dry out all the way.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your cordyline needs a high humidity level. Mist the leaves regularly, place a humidifier nearby, or use a pebble tray to raise the humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your cordyline prefers temperatures between 65-85°F. Avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a liquid houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once a month during the spring and summer. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil; always make sure the soil is damp before feeding your plant.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your cordyline is considered to be toxic to pets and humans if ingested. Can cause stomach irritation and vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Croton Magnificent will do best in a bright spot, as it needs lots of light (if possible 4-6 hrs. Per day) to produce all those colorful leaves! If your croton does not get enough light, you might find the plant grows tall and lanky with spare leaves lacking the rich, dark hues.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25%-50% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Crotons appreciate a generous amount of humidity. You can boost the humidity by misting the leaves, placing a humidifier nearby, or adding a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Croton Magnificent prefers temperatures between 60-70 degrees. Keep your Croton away from drafts and cold areas like a windowpane in the winter.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer once in early spring, once in early summer, and again in mid-summer. Do not feed in the fall or winter.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Don’t panic if your plant drops a few leaves upon arrival. Generally, the Croton Magnificent does not like to be moved, so a few falling leaves within a week doesn’t mean you are doing anything wrong.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Croton Magnificent is moderately toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Croton Petra will do best in a bright spot, as it needs lots of light (if possible 4-6 hrs. Per day) to produce all those colorful leaves! If your croton does not get enough light, you might find the plant grows tall and lanky with spare leaves lacking the rich, dark hues.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25%-50% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Crotons appreciate a generous amount of humidity. You can boost the humidity by misting the leaves, placing a humidifier nearby, or adding a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant prefers temperatures between 60-70 degrees. Keep your Croton Petra away from drafts and cold areas like a windowpane in the winter.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer once in early spring, once in early summer, and again in mid-summer. Do not feed in the fall or winter.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Moderately toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Don’t panic if your plant drops a few leaves upon arrival. Generally, the Croton Petra does not like to be moved, so a few falling leaves within a week doesn’t mean you are doing anything wrong. Make sure you follow the water and light guidelines and, with a little TLC, before you know it you will have fresh, tender leaves that will soon mature to their full, blazing glory!

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Croton prefers indirect bright light to direct light. If your croton does not get enough light, you might find the plant grows tall and lanky with sparse leaves that lack rich, dark hues this plant is known for. If you are worried you do not have the right lighting for this plant, use agrow light!

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Crotonwhen 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Always check the soil moisture before watering. Water thoroughly until you see water flow out of the drainage hole and discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Crotons appreciate a generous amount of humidity. You can boost the humidity bymistingthe leaves, placing a humidifier nearby, or adding a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Croton is most comfortable in temperatures between 60-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month in the spring and summer when it is producing new leaves with ageneral-purpose fertilizerat half strength. Always make sure the soil is damp before applying any fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered moderately toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Don’t panic if your plant drops a few leaves upon arrival. This is a normal stress response common to crotons. Place the plant in the recommended light, water as advised, and allow the plant to adjust to its new environment over the following few weeks. Before you know it you will have fresh, tender leaves that will soon mature to their full, blazing glory!

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ctenanthe will do best in medium to bright indirect light, but will tolerate lower light situations. Do not place this plant in direct sunlight as the leaves will burn.

Title: WATER
Description: For best results, water your Ctenanthe when the top 25-50% of soil is dry. This is not a drought-tolerant indoor plant, but it is relatively forgiving if you forget to water it from time to time. Extended periods of dryness can result in brown leaf tips or edges.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Like many tropical indoor plants, your Ctenanthe prefers a spot with ample humidity. If leaf edges begin to curl or brown up, mist them with lukewarm water on a regular basis. Your bathroom or kitchen are perfect spots for your Ctenanthe because these areas tend to be more humid.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Ctenanthes enjoy the warmth and prefer temperatures between 65-85 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer with iron every four weeks during the spring and summer. No fertilizer is necessary during winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ctenanthes are considered to be non-toxic.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you notice a tip or edge burn often with a yellowish hue at the edge, especially on older leaves, it could be due to your tap water. To solve this, allow your tap water to stand overnight before watering so the chlorine and fluoride can evaporate. Remove any yellow leaves to keep your plant strong and growing. Do not use any shine products on the leaves, instead, clean leaves occasionally with a damp cloth.

Title: LIGHT
Description: A Fishbone Prayer Plant will do best in medium to bright indirect light. Never allow this plant to stand in the direct sunlight–the leaves will fade and become scorched. If there is too little light, the new leaves will appear solid green.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Prayer Plant when the
top 25% of the soil is dry. Water
until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the
pot and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description:
Your Prayer Plant prefers a humid
environment. Mist often.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Fishbone Prayer Plant enjoys the warmth–preferably between 65-85 degrees, so maintain indoor temperatures above 60 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.

Title: FOOD
Description:
Feed once a month during the
spring and summer with a liquid
fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fishbone Prayer Plants are non-toxic and are safe for humans, cats, and dogs.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you notice a tip or edge burn, often with a yellowish hue at the edge, it could be due to your tap water. To solve this, allow your tap water to stand overnight before watering so the chlorine and fluoride can evaporate. Alternative water choices are distilled or rainwater. Remove any yellow leaves to keep your plant strong and growing. If only a portion of the leaf is brown or yellow, go ahead and carefully trim off that portion of the leaf with a sharp pair of scissors or pruning shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dieffenbachia will do best in bright, indirect light. It can also tolerate lower light environments, though growth will slow. Avoid direct sunlight which can burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Dieffenbachia when the soil volume is 50-75% dry. Water thoroughly until it drips out the bottom of the pot, and remove excess water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The Dieffenbachia does fine in average household humidity. It won’t mind an added boost in humidity during the drier months of winter.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dieffenbachia prefers temperatures between 60-80°F. Avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your Dieffenbachia once per month during the spring and summer with a general purpose houseplant fertilizer diluted to half-strength. Be sure the soil is damp; never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dieffenbachia are considered to be toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you notice the tips or edges of your plant’s leaves are turning brown, it could be due to your tap water. You can prevent this by watering with filtered water or rainwater. Remove any yellow leaves to keep your plant strong and growing.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Colorama prefers medium indirect sunlight. Too much direct light can burn the leaves. Pale leaves, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Colorama will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena likes comfortable room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. Do not allow the temperature to fall below 60 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: This plant likes to be fed every two weeks in the spring and summer with a well-balanced plant food at half the recommended strength. No food is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows. Always make sure the soil is damp before applying any fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Colorama leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Your Dracaena Colorama is sensitive to an excess of fluoride which is found in tap water and will present with brown or yellow margins of its leaves. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the fluorides or use rainwater.
When the plant begins to outgrow its space you can regulate the height by cutting off the top to the desired height. The tall, bare cane looks odd for a while, but within a few weeks, new shoots appear as the foliage begins to regrow.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena prefers bright indirect light but can adapt to low light. Too much direct sunlight can burn and bleach the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena Dorado will thrive in average room temperatures, between 60-80 degrees.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Dorado will benefit from a light misting 1-2 times per week, especially in the winter, when the air is dry. Misting also helps keep the foliage clean and dust-free.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Dracaena Dorado every month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose liquid fertilizer, diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Moderately toxic to pets, typically causing mild mouth irritation, stomach irritation, and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rain water.
Wipe the leaves with a soft damp cloth to remove dust as necessary. Take care to clean the undersides of the leaves as well as the upper surfaces. Removing dust opens the pores so your plant can exchange air freely, and it helps prevent pests from taking up residency.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your dracaena can be placed in low to indirect light. Too little light and the foliage will yellow and growth will slow. Too much light and the foliage will burn.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. The leading issue with dracaenas is root rot, so keep on the dry side. Always water until you see it flow out of the drainage hole and discard the excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Dracaenas do well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena will thrive in average room temperatures, between 60-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: The dracaena is slow-growing and does not need much fertilizer. Feed once a month in the spring and summer with general purpose plant food, diluted to half-strength. No fertilizer is necessary during the fall and winter when plant growth naturally slows. Always make sure the soil is damp before applying any fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaenas are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Fragrans prefers medium to bright indirect sunlight but can survive in low light situations. Brown spots on the leaves or pale, bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Leaves with less variegation, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your plant thoroughly and allow the top 75% of the soil to dry before watering again. In low light, allow the soil to dry completely before watering. Water your plant less in the winter, when light levels are lower and growth has slowed. Overwatering will cause leaves to turn yellow and fall off, as well as root rot, and the eventual death of the plant.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant likes average room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. They do not do well in temperatures below 55 degrees. Cold winter drafts and blowing heaters can damage the leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Dracaena Fragrans needs very little plant food. Feed once or twice a year in the spring and summer with a basic houseplant food diluted to half the recommended strength. Too much fertilizer can cause the leaf tips to burn.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Fragrans leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you find the tips of your Dracaena’s leaves begin to turn brown, it may be caused by chemicals in your tap water. Use filtered water, or leave tap water in an open container overnight before watering to allow some of the chemicals to evaporate.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Giganta will tolerate low light but will thrive in medium and indirect light. Do not put your Giganta in hot direct sunlight as it will scorch the leaves. If it is not receiving sufficient light, the newer leaves will narrow.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena will benefit from a light misting 1-2 times per week, especially in the winter, when the air is dry. Misting also helps keep the foliage clean and dust-free.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal temperature for your Giganta is between 65-75 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Giganta monthly during the spring through fall with a liquid houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Giganta is moderately toxic, typically causing mild mouth irritation, stomach indigestion, and possible vomiting if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater. Wipe the leaves with a soft damp cloth to remove dust as necessary. Take care to clean the undersides of the leaves as well as the upper surfaces. Removing dust opens the pores so your plant can exchange air freely, and it helps prevent pests from taking up residency.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Gold Star prefers bright indirect light but can survive in low light. Leaves with less variegation, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light. Too much direct sunlight will burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Gold Star will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena prefers room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. They do not do well in temperatures below 55 degrees. Cold winter drafts and blowing heaters can damage the leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rain water.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Golden Heart does best in low to indirect bright light. Direct sunlight can cause the variegation to fade and can scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena will do well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena likes comfortable room temperatures between 65-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Dracaena once a month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Always make sure the soil is damp before applying any fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Golden Heart leaves are considered toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Green Jewel prefers bright indirect sunlight but can survive in low-light situations. Pale bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Slow growth and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Green Jewel will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant likes average room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. They do not do well in temperatures below 55 degrees. Cold winter drafts and blowing heaters can damage the leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Green Jewel leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you find the tips of your Dracaena’s leaves begin to turn brown, it may be caused by chemicals in your tap water. Use filtered water, rainwater, or leave tap water in an open container overnight before watering to allow some of the chemicals to evaporate.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Jade Jewel prefers medium indirect sunlight but can survive in low-light situations. Pale bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Leaves with less variegation, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Jade Jewel will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant likes average room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. They do not do well in temperatures below 55 degrees. Cold winter drafts and blowing heaters can damage the leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Jade Jewel leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping,’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering or fertilizer burn. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful if built up in the soil. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chlorine and fluoride or you can use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Janet Craig prefers medium indirect sunlight but can survive in low-light situations. Pale bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Pale leaves, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Janet Craig will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena Janet Craig likes comfortable room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. They do not do well in temperatures below 55 degrees. Cold winter drafts and blowing heaters will damage the leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Dracaena Janet Craig needs very little plant food. Feed once or twice a year in the spring and summer with a basic houseplant food at half the recommended strength. Too much fertilizer will cause the leaf tips to burn.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Janet Craig leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering, too much fertilizer, etc.
The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, and fluoride. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chlorine and fluoride or use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Lemon Lime prefers medium indirect sunlight but can survive in low-light situations. Pale bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Pale leaves, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena does not require any additional humidity but will enjoy occasional misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena prefers temperatures between 60-75 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Not toxic to humans. Moderately toxic to pets, typically causing mild mouth irritation, stomach indigestion, and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering, too much fertilizer, etc. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, and fluoride. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chlorine and fluoride or use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Limelight does best in low to indirect bright light. Direct sunlight can cause the lime color to fade and can even scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Dracaena when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Always water thoroughly and discard excess water in the saucer to avoid root rot. Overwatering causes root rot and is the most common reason a Dracaena plant dies.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena will do well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena likes comfortable room temperatures between 65-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: The Dracaena is slow-growing and does not need much fertilizer. Feed once a month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose plant food, diluted to half-strength. No fertilizer is necessary during the fall and winter when plant growth naturally slows. Always make sure the soil is damp before applying any fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Limelight leaves are toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena will do best in medium to bright indirect sunlight, but can tolerate low light.

Title: WATER
Description: Overwatering causes root rot and is the main reason a Dracaena plant dies. Water your Dracaena well and allow the top 50-75% of the soil to dry before watering again. Brown tips on the leaves can indicate over watering while numerous yellow leaves mean the plant needs more water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena will do well in average humidity environments, but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Dracaenas like average room temperatures between 65-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Dracaena plants are slow-growing and do not need much fertilizer. Feed once a month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose plant food at half the recommended strength. No fertilizer is necessary during the fall and winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena is toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rain water.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Marginata prefers medium indirect sunlight but can survive in low light situations. Bleached leaves with dry brown spots usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Pale leaves, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Overwatering causes root rot and is the main reason a Dracaena Marginata plant dies. Water your Marginata well and allow the top 75% of the soil to dry before watering again.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Marginata will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Marginatas like comfortable room temperatures between 65-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Marginata leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering, too much fertilizer, etc. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, and fluoride. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chlorine and fluoride or you can use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Marginata prefers medium indirect sunlight but can survive in low-light situations. Pale bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Pale leaves, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Overwatering causes root rot and is the main reason a Dracaena Marginata plant dies. Water your Marginata well and allow the top 75% of the soil to dry before watering again.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Marginata will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Marginatas like comfortable room temperatures between 65-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Marginata leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering, too much fertilizer, etc. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, and fluoride. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chlorine and fluoride or use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your dracaena can be placed in low to indirect light. Too little light and the foliage will yellow and growth will slow. Too much light and the foliage will burn.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. The leading issue with dracaenas is root rot, so keep on the dry side. Always water until you see it flow out of the drainage hole and discard the excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Dracaenas do well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena will thrive in average room temperatures, between 60-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: The dracaena is slow-growing and does not need much fertilizer. Feed once a month in the spring and summer with general purpose plant food, diluted to half-strength. No fertilizer is necessary during the fall and winter when plant growth naturally slows. Always make sure the soil is damp before applying any fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaenas are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Sol prefers bright indirect light but can survive in low light. Leaves with less variegation, slow growth, and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Overwatering causes root rot and is the main reason a dracaena plant dies. Water your plant thoroughly and allow the top 75% of the soil to dry before watering again. In low light, allow the soil to dry completely before watering. Water your plant less in the winter, when light levels are lower and growth has slowed.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Sol will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your dracaena prefers room temperatures between 65-80°F. They do not do well in temperatures below 55°F. Cold winter drafts and blowing heaters can damage the leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Your dracaena needs very little plant food. Feed twice a year in the spring and summer with liquid houseplant food at half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Song of India prefers bright, indirect sunlight, but can survive in low light situations.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Song of India thoroughly and allow 50–75% of the soil to dry before watering again. In low light, allow the soil to dry completely before watering. Water your plant less in the winter, when light levels are lower and growth has slowed. Overwatering will cause leaves to turn yellow and fall off, as well as root rot, and the eventual death of the plant.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Song of India will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Song of Indias like average room temperatures between 65–80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Song of India leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering or fertilizer burn. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful if built up in the soil. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chlorine or fluoride or you can use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Song of Jamaica prefers bright indirect sunlight, but can survive in medium to low light situations.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Song of Jamaica thoroughly and allow 50-75% of the soil to dry before watering again. Overwatering causes root rot and is the main reason a Dracaena Song of Jamaica plant dies. Yellow leaves indicate that the plant is being kept too wet.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Song of Jamaica will do well in average humidity environments, but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Song of Jamaica likes average room temperatures between 65-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Song of Jamaica leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering, too much fertilizer, etc. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts and excess minerals. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of these minerals or you can use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Tarzan will do best in medium to bright indirect sunlight, but can tolerate low light.

Title: WATER
Description: Overwatering causes root rot and is the main reason a Dracaena plant dies. Water your Dracaena well and allow the top 75% of the soil to dry before watering again. Water thoroughly and discard any excess water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Tarzan will do well in average humidity environments, but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Dracaenas like average room temperatures between 65-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Dracaena plants are slow-growing and do not need much fertilizer. Feed once a month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose plant food at half the recommended strength. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rain water.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dracaena Twister prefers medium indirect sunlight but can survive in low-light situations. Pale bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Slow growth and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. Overwatering will cause leaves to turn yellow and fall off. Overwatering causes root rot and is the main reason a Dracaena plant dies.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Dracaena Twister will do well in average humidity household humidity but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant likes normal room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. They do not do well in temperatures below 55 degrees. Cold winter drafts and blowing heaters can damage the leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Dracaena Twister every month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose liquid fertilizer, diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Twister leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping,’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. This can be caused by a variety of issues like overwatering or fertilizer burn, but the most common cause is tap water.
Tap water contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may build up in the soil over time. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving your tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chlorine and fluoride or use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your dracaena can be placed in low to indirect light. Too little light and the foliage will yellow and growth will slow. Too much light and the foliage will burn.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. The leading issue with dracaenas is root rot, so keep on the dry side. Always water until you see it flow out of the drainage hole and discard the excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Dracaenas do well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Dracaena will thrive in average room temperatures, between 60-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: The dracaena is slow-growing and does not need much fertilizer. Feed once a month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose plant food, diluted to half-strength. No fertilizer is necessary during the fall and winter when plant growth naturally slows. Always make sure the soil is damp before applying any fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Dracaena Warneckii leaves are toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Look out for a common problem called ‘tipping’ when the tips of the leaves dry out and turn brown. The most common cause is tap water, which contains salts, chlorine, fluoride, and other elements that may be harmful in excess. To prevent this, you can use distilled water or rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Lucky Bamboo prefers bright indirect sunlight but can survive in low-light situations. Pale bleached leaves usually indicate the plant is getting too much light. Slow growth and small new leaves indicate it is not getting enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Lucky Bamboo does well in average household humidity. Keep away from any open vents or drafts.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Lucky bamboo is fairly tolerant, doing well in temperatures between 65-95° F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Your Lucky Bamboo does not require much fertilizer. Fertilize once in the early spring with a plant food high in nitrogen.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Lucky Bamboo is toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: You can propagate your lucky bamboo by taking healthy stem cuttings at any point during the year. If you find the tips of your Lucky Bamboo’s leaves begin to turn brown, it may be caused by chemicals in your tap water. Use filtered water, rainwater, or leave tap water in an open container overnight before watering to allow some of the chemicals to evaporate.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dwarf Banana Tree prefers full sun 4-6 hours per day, if possible. Place it in a south-facing window where it will get the most light.

Title: WATER
Description: Allow your plant to dry 25-50% of the way down. Water thoroughly, allowing the water to flow from the drainage hole in the bottom of the pot and into the saucer. Be sure to empty the saucer of all water—never let the plant/roots sit in water it will lead to root rot.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Conditions ranging from 67-80  degrees are fine for your Banana Tree.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant enjoys extra humidity, so feel free to mist daily or place a humidifier nearby.  Another option is to place the container on a pebble tray. Place pebbles an inch or so deep in a plate or tray filled with water. The pebbles keep the plant up out of the water and as the water evaporates, it creates humidity for the plant!

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Banana Tree once a month with a diluted liquid fertilizer. They are known to grow fairly quickly, so this monthly food with help sustain their growth.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Dwarf Banana Tree is non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Wipe the large leaves down occasionally with a damp cloth as they tend to collect dust. Never use household cleaners, as they will clog the pores and burn leaves. Use plain water mixed with a bit of diluted dish soap in a spray bottle. Always remove the dead foliage from the plant and soil—this can provide a breeding ground for pests and disease. Do not expect to actually harvest fruit from your Banana Tree.  Indoors, your plant will not be in the right conditions to flower and grow fruit.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Easter lilies love to be placed in indirect, bright sunlight. Too much light will burn the foliage, but too little light will cause the slow decline of the plant. Eastern light or a few feet back from a southern window is ideal.

Title: WATER
Description: Easter lilies prefer to stay somewhat moist. Water when 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly and discard excess water to avoid root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Easter lily prefers a humid environment. Place a humidifier nearby or use a pebble tray. Avoid drafty areas and open vents.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Easter lilies prefer cooler temperatures between 60-75°F. The cooler the temperature, the longer the blooms will last.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Easter lily fertilizer in the spring when new shoots emerge.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Easter lilies are toxic to humans and pets if ingested. All parts of the Easter lily, including the pollen, are extremely toxic to cats.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: As the Easter lily grows it can become quite top-heavy. Stake your plant to help it reach its full height potential.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your euonymus will love bright, indirect sunlight. Avoid placing it in direct sunlight as this may cause the leaves to burn and turn white. Eastern exposure or a few feet back from a southern or western window is ideal.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly until you see it flow out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water to avoid root rot. Your euonymus needs less water during the winter dormant season.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The leathery leaves of the euonymus plant can adapt to dry air, making it a great houseplant. However, your plant won’t mind added humidity especially in the winter months.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Euonymus plants do well in temperatures between 60-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: During the spring and summer, fertilize with a well-balanced fertilizer once a month.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The euonymus plant is toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Once the blooms begin to wilt and die off in the fall and winter, you can prune them to maintain a nice shape. The Euonymus will need trimming from time to time. This should keep them full of leaves instead of looking leggy.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your euphorbia needs bright direct light. This means a spot that gets 6 plus hours of direct sun per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your euphorbia when the soil volume is 100% dry. Water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole. Discard excess water to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Euphorbias do well in dry to average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your euphorbia prefers temperatures between 60-90°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once in the spring and summer with a cacti or succulent fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The euphorbias are toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Be sure to wear gloves when handling your euphorbia as it oozes a milky substance that is irritating to the skin and eyes if handled incorrectly.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Candelabra Cactus will do well in bright light to full sun. If it doesn’t receive enough light, the branches and stems will become leggy and stretched out.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water only when the soil is completely dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at
the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant requires no additional humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Candelabra Cactus prefers temperatures between 60-85 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Before applying any type of plant food, make sure the soil is already damp-never apply to dry soil. Your Candelabra Cactus requires fertilizer once in the spring and once in the summer. Apply an all-purpose, liquid plant food diluted to half strength. Do not fertilize your Candelabra in the fall or winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Candelabra Cactus is moderately toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you notice a white, crusty substance on the soil surface of a Candelabra Cactus, it is fertilizer salt that needs to be flushed from the soil. Remove the salt layer if it’s thick, and then water the plant slowly with twice the volume of water that the pot holds. Allow the soil to drain completely, and don’t let the pot stand in water. The fertilizer salt-flushing procedure can be done 1-2 times each year if it is necessary.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Crown of Flowers prefers bright indirect light. Direct morning sunlight is fine for this plant, but avoid prolonged exposure to direct sun which can scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Add water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil until it flows through the drainage hole. Discard water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant does well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant prefers temperatures between 60-90°F. Avoid drafty areas and temperatures below 55°F in the winter.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed monthly during periods of active growth with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Crown of Flowers growth will naturally slow in the winter and watering frequency should be reduced. Stems can be cut back to reduce the plant’s height and will bear new leaves and flowers in the spring. Cutting the plant produces a milky sap that can irritate sensitive skin.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ghost Cactus needs bright direct light. This means a spot that gets 6 plus hours of direct sun per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Ghost Cactus when the soil volume is 100% dry. Water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil, until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot. Discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Ghost Cacti do well in dry to average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ghost Cactus prefers temperatures between 60-90°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once in the spring and summer with a cacti or succulent fertilizer. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ghost Cacti are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Be sure to wear gloves when handling your plant as it oozes a milky substance that is irritating to the skin and eyes if handled incorrectly.

Title: LIGHT
Description: The Pencil Cactus needs bright direct light. This means a spot that gets 6 or more hours of direct sun per day like an unobstructed southern or western window.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your euphorbia when the soil volume is 100% dry. Water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole. Discard excess water to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Euphorbias do well in dry to average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your euphorbia prefers temperatures between 60-90°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once in the spring and summer with a cacti or succulent fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Pencil Cactus is toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Be sure to wear gloves when handling the Pencil Cactus as it oozes a milky substance that is irritating to skin and eyes if handled incorrectly. You can easily propagate your euphorbia by cuttings. Use a sharp knife to make a clean cut at a stem joint. Allow the cut surface to callus over for a week and pot with fresh cactus soil. Withhold water for a week before watering normally. You should see roots taking hold in a month or so.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Poinsettias love bright but indirect sunlight. An eastern window is ideal, or a few feet back from a southern or western window. Watch out for pale bleached leaves as this is a sign your plant is getting too much direct sun.

Title: WATER
Description: You should water your poinsettia when the top 50% of soil is dry. Water slowly until you see water begin to trickle out of the pot’s drainage hole, and make sure you let excess water fully drain out. Discard any excess water after a few minutes.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Poinsettias enjoy humidity between 50% – 75% ambient humidity. You can boost humidity by misting, adding a pebble tray, or placing a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Poinsettia flowers appreciate daytime temperatures between 65-75° F and nighttime temperatures of 55-60° F. Keep your poinsettia away from drafty windows or doors, and any open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: You can give your poinsettia a boost with fertilizer for flowering plants. Fertilize once a month after the plant begins growing again in the spring and throughout the growing season and into the fall. No fertilizer is needed during the winter months.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Toxic only if ingested in very high amounts to pets and humans. The sap can be irritating to the mouth and stomach if ingested, sometimes causing vomiting. The sap may also cause a very mild allergic skin reaction in some people.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: To encourage your plant to take on a full, bushy shape, prune the stems back in spring and allow the plant to flush out new growth. To encourage the plant to rebloom, ensure the plant receives complete darkness for 14 hours a day for a span of 8 weeks, beginning in mid to late September. This signals the plant to begin producing flower buds and colorful bracts in time for the holiday season.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Fatsia Japonica prefers bright indirect light when grown indoors. It can also tolerate a few hours of direct sunlight through a window as well. When grown outdoors, your Fatsia should be placed in a shady spot as direct sun may burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Fatsia when the soil is about 50-75% dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Fatsia will do fine with average room humidity, but will appreciate added humidity from a humidifier or occasional misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Fatsia prefers average room temperatures of 60-75 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Fatsia 1-2 times a month during spring and summer with a general houseplant fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fatsia is non-toxic according to the ASPCA. However, the sap may cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals, so use gloves when pruning and repotting, and wash your hands afterward.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Fatsia can be very quick growing during spring and summer. You can choose to prune it to keep it to a certain size. If you do not do this, you may find that it can outgrow its pot within 6 months to a year. Keep an eye on it and repot it when the time comes to keep your plant healthy.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Autumn Fern prefers bright indirect light. Too much direct light will burn the foliage, and too little light will cause its signature autumnal colors to fade. Try using agrow lightif you are worried you do not have enough light in your space.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Autumn Fernwhen 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly until you see water flow out of the drainage hole, and discard the excess water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The Autumn Fern prefers a humid environment. If the air in your home is dry, use a pebble tray or place a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Autumn Fern plants can grow in temperatures between 60-80°F. Keep away from drafty areas or open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your fern once a month in the spring and summer with ageneral-purpose indoor plant fertilizerat half-strength. There’s no need to feed in the fall or winter when the plant goes into a natural resting period.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Autumn Fern is non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: As the plant grows, the lower, older fronds will naturally turn brown. Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy new growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean,sharp pruning scissorsorplant snips.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Bird’s Nest Fern will do best in medium to low light. The more light it receives, the more the leaves will crinkle and the less light, the flatter the leaves will be. Keep in mind, too much light or extended periods of direct sunlight will cause the fronds on the fern to get a pale bleached color.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water when the top 25% of the soil
is dry. When watering, water only
the soil – not the leaves. Water
accumulating in the crown of your
plant could lead to bacterial growth
and potential leaf rot. Water until
liquid flows through the drainage
hole at the bottom of the pot
and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description:
This plant likes a humid
environment, like a bathroom
or kitchen. Mist often.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This fern will enjoy a warm area, preferably between 68-80 degrees, so maintain indoor temperatures above 60 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.

Title: FOOD
Description:
Feed once a month during the
spring and summer with a liquid
fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Bird’s Nest Ferns are non-poisonous plants and safe for humans, dogs and cats.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Regularly remove any dead fronds
from the plant to encourage healthy
new growth. Cut stems at the soil
line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Button Fern will thrive in low to bright indirect light. Take care to avoid direct sun exposure, as it will scorch the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Button Fern requires an environment with higher humidity, making it the perfect bathroom or kitchen plant. Throughout the dryer times of the year, use a pebble tray, a humidifier, or frequent misting to help boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal temperature for your Button Fern is between 60-75 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and direct air from heating and cooling vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once every month during the spring and summer. No need to feed your plant in the winter, when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer, make sure the soil is damp. Never apply to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Button Ferns are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Watch for fronds that are yellowing and wilted, these are signs of overwatering. Brown leaf tips are caused by high temperatures (above 80 degrees) or dry air. Trim off any dry leaflets and raise the humidity around your plant.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Crocodile Fern will do best in bright indirect to low light. A northern or eastern window provides the best light exposure. Turn the plant once or twice each month to encourage even growth.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description:
Your Button Fern requires an environment with higher humidity, making it the perfect bathroom or kitchen plant. Throughout the dryer times of the year, use a pebble tray, a humidifier, or frequent misting to help boost humidity.
 A kitchen or bathroom is an ideal environment for your Crocodile Fern, as these areas are naturally higher in humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This fern will enjoy a warm area, preferably between 68-80 degrees, so maintain indoor temperatures above 60 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.

Title: FOOD
Description: Use a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once a month during spring and summer months. Make sure the soil is thoroughly damp before fertilizing–never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Crocodile Ferns are non-poisonous plants and safe for humans, dogs, and cats.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim off crowded fronds with clean, sharp shears to encourage airflow. This will help reduce the possibility of fungal infections.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your East Indian Holly Fern prefers bright indirect light but will adapt to medium light conditions. Take care to avoid direct sun exposure, as it will scorch the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your East Indian Holly Fern when the top 25% of the soil becomes dry. When watering, thoroughly drench until the water drains into the saucer. Empty the saucer of any standing water so as not to drown the roots.
Maintaining the correct soil moisture is key to keeping your East Indian Holly Fern happy and healthy. Keep your East Indian Holly Fern’s soil consistently moist, but not soggy, and avoid allowing your fern to dry out completely.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Holly Fern will appreciate added humidity. Kitchens and bathrooms are great spots for your fern. Mist often, place a humidifier nearby or use a pebble tray to boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your East Indian Holly Fern will thrive in normal room temperatures between 60–80 degrees. It can tolerate periods of colder temperatures, but for best results keep it in warmer temperatures.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your fern once a month during the spring to the end of summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your East Indian Holly Fern is non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy new growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Emina Ferns will thrive in low to bright indirect light. Take care to avoid direct sun exposure, as it will scorch the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Emina Fern requires an environment with higher humidity, making it the perfect bathroom or kitchen plant. Throughout the dryer times of the year, use a pebble tray, a humidifier, or frequent misting to help boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This beautiful fern does not like being cold and does best when the temperature is between 60-75 degrees. If the temperature falls below 60 degrees, it will stop growing. Avoid cold drafts and sudden temperature changes.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general all-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer once every month during the spring and summer. Never feed a fern when the soil is dry, it will burn the fronds.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Emina Ferns are non-poisonous to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy, rich, and green growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean, sharp shears. If you wish to boost the fern’s vigor and deepen the plant’s color, supplement regular fertilizing once during the spring and again in midsummer with 2 tablespoons of Epsom salts dissolved in a gallon of water.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Blue Star Fern prefers bright indirect light but will adapt to lower lighting conditions. It will not tolerate direct sunlight, as the foliage will burn.

Title: WATER
Description: Your Blue Star Fern is relatively hardy and will tolerate soil that dries out from time to time, but it prefers its soil to be kept moist–never wet or soggy. Water when 50% of the soil volume has dried out. Always water thoroughly until water flows out of the drainage hole and discard any water left in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Blue Star Fern will do just fine in average household humidity but will appreciate a boost in humidity through regular misting or adding a humidifier nearby. Your bathroom and kitchen are great spots to keep your Blue Star Fern, as these areas are most humid.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once a month during the spring and summer. Make sure soil is moist before fertilizing. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Blue Star Fern will thrive in average room temperatures between 65-80°F. Avoid placing it near forced-air vents or drafty doors and windows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Blue Star Fern is non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Regularly remove any dead fronds from your plant to encourage lush new growth. Cut stems close to the soil line with clean, sharp snips.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Kangaroo Fern prefers bright indirect light, but will adapt to lower lighting conditions. It will not tolerate direct sunlight, as the foliage will burn.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. This Fern can tolerate drying out a little, but never all the way.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Kangaroo Fern will do just fine in average household humidity, but will appreciate a boost in humidity through regular misting, a pebble tray, or adding a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Kangaroo Fern will thrive in average room temperatures between 65-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once a month during the spring and summer. Make sure soil is moist before fertilizing. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Kangaroo Fern is non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Regularly remove any dead fronds from your plant to encourage healthy, rich, and green growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Kimberly Queen Fern prefers bright, indirect light, but can survive in the direct sun if it’s watered on a regular basis and the soil remains moist.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Fern requires an environment with higher humidity, making it the perfect bathroom or kitchen plant. Throughout the dryer times of the year, use a pebble tray, a humidifier, or frequent misting to help boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This beautiful fern does not like to be cold, so it’s best to keep the temperature between 65-80 degrees. If the temperature falls below 60 degrees, it will stop growing.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer at half strength once every three months. Never feed a fern when the soil is dry, it will burn the fronds.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Kimberly Queen Ferns are non-poisonous to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy, rich, and green growth. Make sure your Kimberly Queen Fern is not in a drafty area in your home or office.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Lemon Button Fern will thrive in medium to bright indirect light. Take care to avoid direct sun exposure, as it will scorch the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Lemon Button Fern requires an environment with higher humidity, making it the perfect bathroom or kitchen plant. Throughout the dryer times of the year, use a pebble tray, a humidifier, or frequent misting to help boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal temperature for your Lemon Button Fern is between 60-75 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and direct air from heating and cooling vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once every month during the spring and summer. No need to feed your plant in the winter, when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer, make sure the soil is damp. Never apply to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Lemon Button Ferns are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Watch for fronds that are yellowing and wilted, these are signs of overwatering. Brown leaf tips are caused by high temperatures (above 80 degrees) or dry air. Trim off any dry leaflets and raise the humidity around your plant with regular misting or a pebble tray.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Mahogany Fern prefers bright indirect light but will adapt to lower light conditions. Keep out of direct sunlight, as it can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The Mahogany Fern will appreciate added humidity. Kitchens and bathrooms are great spots for your fern. Misting often, place a humidifier nearby, or use a pebble tray to boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Mahogany Fern will thrive in normal room temperatures between 65-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your fern once a month during the spring to end of summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Mahogany Fern is non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy new growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Maidenhair Fern in low to indirect bright light. Too little light and growth will slow, but too much light can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: The Maidenhair Fern does not tolerate dry conditions. Keep the soil moist by watering when 25% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly until you see it flow out of the drainage hole and discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your fern prefers a humid environment. Place a humidifier nearby or use a pebble tray. Kitchens and bathrooms are also great spots for your fern.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern will thrive in normal room temperatures between 65-80°F. Keep your fern away from blowing air or drafty areas, as it can cause damage to its delicate leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your fern once a month during the spring and summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Maidenhair Fern is non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: It is normal to see occasional leaf browning due to age or if the plant got too dry. Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy new growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Maidenhair Blush Fern prefers bright indirect light but will adapt to medium light conditions. Keep out of direct sunlight, as it can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. This plant will not tolerate drying out.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern will appreciate added humidity. Kitchens and bathrooms are great spots for your fern. Mist often, place a humidifier nearby, or use a pebble tray to boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern will thrive in normal room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. Keep your Fern away from blowing air or drafty areas, as it can cause damage to its delicate leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your fern once a month during the spring to end of summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern is non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: As this plant is rather particular with humidity, it is normal to see occasional leaf browning. Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy new growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern prefers bright indirect light but will adapt to medium light conditions. Keep out of direct sunlight, as it can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. This plant will not tolerate drying out.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern will appreciate added humidity. Kitchens and bathrooms are great spots for your fern. Mist often, place a humidifier nearby or use a pebble tray to boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern will thrive in normal room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. Keep your Fern away from blowing air or drafty areas, as it can cause damage to its delicate leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your fern once a month during the spring to end of summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Maidenhair Fern is non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: As this plant is rather particular with humidity, it is normal to see occasional leaf browning. Regularly remove any dead fronds from the plant to encourage healthy new growth. Cut stems at the soil line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Rabbit Foot Fern in low to indirect bright light. Too little light and growth with slow, but too much light can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water in the saucer to avoid root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your fern does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind added humidity if leaves begin to crisp.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Prefers temperatures between 60-75°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once a month during the growing season with a well-balanced fertilizer. No fertilizer is needed during dormancy.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Rabbit Foot Fern is non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
