Description: You can propagate your Rabbit Foot Fern by cutting off a 1-2” section of fuzzy rhizome, preferably one with a frond or two. Place the cutting in a pot with a peat-based soil mix or sphagnum moss. Keep the growing medium moist and place in a warm humid spot.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Silver Lace Fern will thrive in medium to bright indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight–it will scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The Silver Lace Fern will appreciate a bit of extra humidity.  Mist frequently, place a humidifier nearby or use a pebble tray to increase humidity levels.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal room temperature for your Silver Lace Fern is between 55-75 degrees. If the temperature falls below 55 degrees, it will stop growing. Avoid drafts and direct air from heating and cooling vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer diluted to half strength once every month during the spring and summer. No need to feed your plant in the winter, when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer, make sure the soil is damp. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Silver Lace Ferns are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: For best results, water with filtered water. If you don’t have a filtration system, let tap water sit overnight to evaporate any harsh chemicals and then use the next day or use rainwater.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your fern prefers bright indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight, which can scorch the foliage, or too little light which causes slow growth.

Title: WATER
Description: Your fern prefers its soil to be kept moist–never wet or soggy. Water when 25% of the soil volume has dried out. Always water thoroughly until water flows out of the drainage hole and discard any water left in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your fern will do just fine in average household humidity, but crispy brown tips can indicate the humidity is too low. In this case, add a pebble tray or place a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your fern will thrive in average room temperatures between 60-80°F. Avoid placing it near forced-air vents or drafty doors and windows.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once a month during the spring and summer. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil; make sure the soil is moist before fertilizing.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your fern is non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Regularly remove any dead fronds from your plant to encourage lush new growth. Cut stems close to the soil line with clean, sharp snips.

Title: LIGHT
Description: The Silver Ribbon Fern thrives in medium to bright indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight, as it will scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The Silver Ribbon Fern will appreciate a bit of extra humidity.  Throughout the dryer times of the year, use a pebble tray, place a humidifier nearby or mist often.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal temperature for your Silver Ribbon Fern is between 55-75 degrees. If the temperature falls below 55 degrees, it will stop growing. Avoid drafts and direct air from heating and cooling vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer at half the recommended strength once every month during the spring and summer. There is no need to feed your plant in the winter, when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer make sure the soil is damp–never apply to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Silver Ribbon Ferns are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: LIGHT
Description: With a sharp pair of scissors or pruning shears, trim off the older, outer fronds of Silver Ribbon Fern if they become shabby-looking. This makes room for new fronds ready to unfurl from the many growing points on the rhizome.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Staghorn Fern will thrive in medium to bright indirectlight. It will not do well in low light situations.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 25% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Staghorn Fern absorbs water through its fronds as well as its roots. This means that they respond well to misting and appreciate extra humidity. Throughout the dryer times of the year, use a pebble tray to increase humidity place a humidifier nearby, or mist regularly.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal temperature for your Staghorn Fern is between 50-85 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and direct air from a heating and cooling vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer once every month during the spring and summer. No need to feed your plant in the winter, when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer, make sure the soil is damp. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Staghorn Ferns are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Regularly remove any dead fronds
from the plant to encourage healthy
new growth. Cut stems at the soil
line with clean, sharp shears.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Burgundy Rubber Tree prefers bright indirect light. Direct sunlight in the morning or late afternoon is fine, but avoid harsh midday sun which may cause leaf scorch. This plant does not tolerate low light.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water when 50%-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water slowly so that
it soaks into the soil until it flows through the drainage hole at the
bottom of the pot. Discard any excess water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Rubber Tree does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind added humidity with a pebble tray or nearby humidifier.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The Burgundy Rubber Tree enjoys temperatures from 60° – 80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter months when growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Rubber Trees are sensitive to being moved. If you have to move your plant to a drastically different spot, do so gradually. Any sudden changes can cause leaves to drop. When pruning your plant, be careful of the milky latex substance that may leak out where cuts have occurred—this is a mildly toxic irritant. If you get the sap on your hands or skin, wash with warm water and soap immediately.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Ficus Alii in bright indirect or filtered light. Avoid bright direct light as it will burn the leaves and cause them to drop.

Title: WATER
Description: Water with room-temperature water once the soil dries 50-75% down. Water thoroughly until water flows into the saucer, then pour out any excess.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus tree will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus Alii will thrive in average temperatures of 60-75 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your Ficus tree every month in late spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer diluted to half strength. You will see new leaves appear and branches grow during this time. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ficus Alii leaves are mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Ficus are sensitive to changes in their environment. They react to these changes by dropping leaves. If you have just moved your Ficus to a new location, expect the leaves to drop. The leaves will begin growing again when the plant adjusts to its new location. If it has not been moved, it could be the result of a change in lighting conditions as the seasons change. Or, it may be reacting to an increase or decrease in its watering frequency.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Keep your ficus in bright indirect light. This plant will not tolerate low light and variegation will fade. Close to an eastern window or just a few feet back from a southern or western window is ideal.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Always water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole to encourage a healthy root system. Discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The Ficus Altissima does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind an extra humidity boost.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus Altissima enjoys average room temperatures of 60-80°F. Avoid drafty areas or open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your ficus once a month from spring through summer with a general houseplant fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Ficus is toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When pruning your plant, make sure to watch out for the milky latex substance that could leak out where cuts have occurred—this is a mildly toxic irritant. If you get the sap on your hands or skin, wash with warm water and soap immediately.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ficus prefers bright indirect light. Direct sun may burn the leaves and cause them to drop.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Ficus Audrey when the top 50-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus Audrey will thrive in average household humidity but will appreciate a boost in humidity from time to time. Regular misting, using a pebble tray, or placing a humidifier nearby are great ways to increase humidity for your Ficus.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus Audrey enjoys average room temperatures of 60-80 degrees. Avoid temperatures below 55 degrees, sudden temperature drops, or cold drafts.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your Ficus once a month from spring through summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ficus leaves are mildly toxic to humans and pets. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Ficus plants are sensitive to being moved. If you have to move your plant around, do so gradually. Any sudden changes can cause leaves to drop. When pruning your plant, be careful of the milky latex substance that may leak out where cuts have occurred—this is a mildly toxic irritant. If you get the sap on your hands or skin, wash with warm water and soap immediately.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Ficus Benjamina in bright indirect or filtered light. Avoid bright direct light as it can burn the leaves and cause them to drop.

Title: WATER
Description: Allow 75% of the soil to dry between watering. When watering, water thoroughly until water flows into the saucer, then pour out any excess.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus tree will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus Benjamina will thrive in average temperatures of 60-75 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your Ficus tree once a month in late spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer diluted to half strength. You will see new growth during this time. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ficus Benjamina leaves are mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Ficus are sensitive to changes in their environment. They react to these changes by dropping leaves. If you have just moved your Ficus to a new location, expect some leaves to drop. If it has not been moved, it could be the result of a change in lighting conditions as the seasons change. It may also be reacting to an increase or decrease in its watering frequency.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ficus Danielle prefers very bright indirect light. Too little light can cause slow growth and decline of the plant.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus tree will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus Danielle will thrive in average temperatures of 60-75°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your Ficus tree every four weeks in late spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer diluted to half strength. You will see new leaves appear and branches grow during this time. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ficus Danielle leaves are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: You can prune your Ficus Danielle during the growing season to keep its classically round shape. When pruning your plant, make sure to watch out for the milky latex substance that could leak out where cuts have occurred–this is a mildly toxic irritant. If you get the sap on your hands or skin, wash with warm water and soap immediately.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ficus Ginseng will be happiest if placed in a spot where it can receive very bright indirect light.  It will not tolerate low light. Direct sun may burn the leaves and cause them to drop.

Title: WATER
Description: Waterwhen 50%-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus prefers a humid environment. Keep a humidifier nearby or create a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus prefers temperatures between 60-80°F. Keep your plant away from blowing air or cold drafts, as this could cause leaves to fall off.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with ageneral-purpose fertilizerfor indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Your Ficus Ginseng is a relatively slow-growing plant and won’t need to be repotted very often, only once every 1-3 years. You canpruneyour Ficus during spring and summer to maintain its small size to reduce the need for repotting.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ficus Repens Green enjoys bright indirect light. It is best to place this plant near an eastern or western facing window.

Title: WATER
Description: Your Ficus does not like to dry out completely–water thoroughly when the top 50-75% of the soil is dry. When watering, water enough so that water flows into the saucer, but never let water sit in the saucer for extended periods of time. This can lead to root rot and the eventual death of your plant.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus will do well in average household humidity but will benefit greatly from a humidifier, pebble tray, or frequent misting to boost humidity. Another way to increase relative humidity is to group several humidity-loving plants together in a small area, creating a micro-climate.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus likes normal room temperatures between 60-80 degrees. Avoid cold winter drafts and direct airflow from heating vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Your Ficus will benefit from regular fertilizing during the spring through fall. Feed with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength every month.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Even though mature plants can produce edible fruits, your Ficus Repens excretes a milky sap that is toxic and can cause skin irritation and inflammation. Keep it away from pets and children.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: To attain a dramatic and fun look in your home, you can let you Ficus Repens vine up on walls. If you have a textured wall, your Ficus will use its aerial roots to grab on by itself, or you can use hooks to help it vine in the direction that you want. Fun fact: the aerial roots secrete a latex substance to help attach to surfaces. This substance is a skin irritant, so be careful!

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Ficus Spire in bright indirect or filtered light. Avoid bright direct light as it will burn the leaves and cause them to drop.

Title: WATER
Description: Water with room-temperature water once the topsoil 50–75% is dry. Water thoroughly until water flows into the saucer, then pour out any excess.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus tree will do well in average humidity environments but will appreciate regular misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus Spire will thrive in average temperatures of 60-75 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your Ficus tree every month in late spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer diluted to half strength. You will see new leaves appear and branches grow during this time. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ficus Spire leaves are mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Ficus are sensitive to changes in their environment. They react to these changes by dropping leaves. If you have just moved your Ficus to a new location, expect the leaves to drop. The leaves will begin growing again when the plant adjusts to its new location. If it has not been moved, it could be the result of a change in lighting conditions as the seasons change. Or, it may be reacting to an increase or decrease in its watering frequency.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ficus Tineke prefers bright, indirect light. Your plant may lose its beautiful cream variegation on new leaves if it’s not receiving enough light. If you are worried you don’t have enough light for your plant, consider using agrow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your plantwhen 50%-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Ficus Tineke will do great in average household humidity but will appreciate a boost in humidity from time to time. Regularmisting, using a pebble tray, or placing a humidifier nearby are great ways to increase humidity for your Ficus.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Ficus Tineke enjoys average room temperatures of 60-80°F. Avoid temperatures below 55°F, sudden temperature drops, or cold drafts.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your Ficus Tineke once a month from spring through summer with ageneral houseplant fertilizerdiluted to half the recommended strength. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter months when growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is mildly toxic to humans and pets. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting. The sap can cause skin irritation.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Your Ficus will excrete a milky latex sap where cuts have occurred. This substance can irritate sensitive skin and stain clothing or other items. Take precautions to protect your hands and work area when pruning this plant, and wash with soap and water if contact does occur.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ficus Umbellata requires bright indirect light. Rotate the pot regularly to encourage even, balanced growth. It can tolerate a few hours of direct morning sun, but avoid exposing the leaves to the harsh afternoon sun. This plant does not tolerate low light conditions.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Ficus when the top 50% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: As a native to the tropics, Ficus Umbellata appreciates extra humidity. Mist the leaves to increase humidity around your plant, especially in the drier winter months.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The Ficus Umbellata enjoys warmer temperatures between 65-85°F. It will not tolerate cold drafts so make sure you avoid placing your plant in drafty areas.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your plant once during the spring and monthly throughout the summer. A little bit of food will go a long way to encourage growth and root health. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ficus leaves are mildly toxic to humans and pets. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Large leaves can collect dust. If you notice the leaves are dirty or dusty, wipe them with a damp cloth and gently dry to keep them clean and healthy. Ficus generally do not like to be moved — if necessary to move your plant, be prepared for some leaf drop until it is acclimated again in a few weeks.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Keep your fiddle leaf fig in bright indirect light. This plant will not tolerate low light and its leaves will eventually yellow and drop. Close to an eastern window or acclimated to the direct light from a southern window is ideal.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Always water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole to encourage a healthy root system. Discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The fiddle leaf fig does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind an extra humidity boost.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your fiddle leaf fig enjoys average room temperatures of 60-80°F. Avoid drafty areas or open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your plant once during the spring and monthly throughout the summer. Over-fertilizing can cause the fiddle leaf fig to grow leggy and can even kill it. A little bit of food will go a long way to encourage growth and root health. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fiddle leaf figs are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When pruning your plant, watch out for the milky latex substance that leaks out where cuts have occurred—this is a mildly toxic irritant. If you get the sap on your hands or skin, wash with warm water and soap immediately.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your fig tree prefers direct sunlight. Place your plant in a full sun location that receives 7+ hours of direct sunlight per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot. Do not use a saucer outdoors or allow the plant to sit in standing water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Average household humidity is fine for most areas of the US

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant is hardy in zones 7-9. Bring indoors when the temperatures dip below 20°F. Plants can be damaged when temperatures drop below 15°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once during the spring and once during the fall with a balanced water soluble fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested. Sap can cause skin irritation. The fruit alone is considered non toxic to humans.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
If keeping this plant outdoors, bring your fig tree inside to winterize once the temperature falls to 20 degrees at night. During this dormant time, water sparingly and do not fertilize. This self pollinating plant will fruit in the fall if care requirements are met. 
Your fig tree’s fruit will ripen on the tree. Be sure to harvest ripe fruit before they drop to avoid messy ripe fruit falling to the ground.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Variegated Ficus prefers bright, indirect light. Your plant may lose its beautiful red variegation on new leaves if it’s not receiving enough light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Variegated Ficus will thrive in average household humidity but will appreciate a boost in humidity from time to time. Regular misting, using a pebble tray, or placing a humidifier nearby are great ways to increase humidity for your Ficus.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Variegated Ficus enjoys average room temperatures of 60-80 degrees. Avoid temperatures below 55 degrees, sudden temperature drops, or cold drafts.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your Variegated Ficus once a month from spring through summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Ficus leaves are mildly toxic to humans and pets. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When pruning your plant, make sure to watch out for the milky latex substance that could leak out where cuts have occurred–this is a mildly toxic irritant. If you get the sap on your hands or skin, wash with warm water and soap immediately.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Keep your fiddle leaf fig in bright indirect light. This plant will not tolerate low light and its leaves will eventually yellow and drop. Close to an eastern window or acclimated to the direct light from a southern window is ideal.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Always water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole to encourage a healthy root system. Discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The fiddle leaf fig does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind an extra humidity boost.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your fiddle leaf fig enjoys average room temperatures of 60-80°F. Avoid drafty areas or open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your plant once during the spring and monthly throughout the summer. Over-fertilizing can cause the fiddle leaf fig to grow leggy and can even kill it. A little bit of food will go a long way to encourage growth and root health. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fiddle leaf figs are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When pruning your plant, watch out for the milky latex substance that leaks out where cuts have occurred—this is a mildly toxic irritant. If you get the sap on your hands or skin, wash with warm water and soap immediately.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your fiddle leaf fig will grow best with consistent, indirect bright light. Turn the plant every few months once it begins to lean towards the light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil becomes dry, then thoroughly drench until the water drains into the saucer. Empty the saucer if the water level is high so as not to drown the roots.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: As a native to the tropics, fiddle leaf figs thrive in warm, wet conditions. Mist the leaves to increase humidity around your plant, especially in the drier winter months.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The fiddle leaf fig enjoys warmer temperatures, but it adapts easily to your home or office climate. However, it will not tolerate cold drafts so make sure you seal up drafty areas before situating your fig.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your plant once during the spring and monthly throughout the summer. Over-fertilizing can cause the fiddle leaf fig to grow leggy and can even kill it. A little bit of food will go a long way to encourage growth and root health. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fiddle leaf fig leaves are mildly toxic to humans and pets. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Large leaves can collect dust. If you notice the leaves are dirty or dusty, wipe them with a damp cloth and gently dry to keep them clean and healthy. You can also add a teaspoon of dishwashing detergent to one gallon of water as a precaution against insects. Fiddle leaf figs do not like to be moved—if necessary to move your plant, be prepared for some leaf drop until it is acclimated again in approximately 2-3 weeks.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Little Fiddle Leaf Fig will grow best with consistent, indirect bright light. Turn the plant every few months once it begins to lean towards the light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the soil is 50-75% dried, then thoroughly drench until the water drains into the saucer. Empty the saucer if the water level is high so as not to drown the roots.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: As a native to the tropics, Fiddle Leaf Figs thrive in warm, wet conditions. Mist the leaves to increase humidity around your plant, especially in the drier winter months.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The Fiddle Leaf Fig enjoys warmer temperatures, but it adapts easily to your home or office climate. However, it will not tolerate cold drafts so make sure you seal up drafty areas before situating your fig.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your plant once during the spring and monthly throughout the summer. Overfertilizing can cause the Fiddle Leaf Fig to grow leggy and can even kill it. A little bit of food will go a long way to encourage growth and root health. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fiddle Leaf Fig leaves are mildly toxic to humans and pets. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Large leaves can collect dust. If you notice the leaves are dirty or dusty, wipe them with a damp cloth and gently dry to keep them clean and healthy. You can also add a teaspoon of dishwashing detergent to one gallon of water as a precaution against insects. Fiddle Leaf Figs do not like to be moved—if necessary to move your plant, be prepared for some leaf drop until it is acclimated again in approximately 2–3 weeks.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Ficus Bonsai will grow best with consistent, bright, filtered light. Turn the plant every few months once it begins to lean towards the light. It will prefer an east-facing, sunny window as afternoon sun from the south or west-facing window will be too strong and may burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the soil is 75% dried, then thoroughly drench until the water drains into the saucer. Empty the saucer if the water level is high so as not to drown the roots. If your plant does not get enough water, the leaves will become limp and floppy, eventually turning brown or yellow before falling off.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: As a native to the tropics, Fiddle Leaf Figs thrive in warm, wet conditions. Mist the leaves to increase humidity around your plant, especially in the drier winter months.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The Fiddle Leaf Fig enjoys warmer temperatures, but it adapts easily to your home or office climate. However, it will not tolerate cold drafts so make sure you seal up drafty areas before situating your fig.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, feed your plant once during the spring and monthly throughout the summer. Overfertilizing can cause the Fiddle Leaf Fig to grow leggy and can even kill it. A little bit of food will go a long way to encourage growth and root health. No fertilizer is necessary during the winter when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fiddle Leaf Fig leaves are mildly toxic to humans and pets. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: As this plant is a bonsai, regular pruning is required to keep its compact shape. As the leaves grow, cut them back to keep growth small.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Fittonia prefers bright, indirect light. Lower light can cause it to lose some of its vibrant color and growth will slow. Too much light can burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Your Fittonia loves water and to be consistently moist, but not soggy. Water thoroughly when the top 50% of soil is dry. If you let your Fittonia dry out too much, it will let you know with limp leaves. Not to worry! After a thorough watering, the leaves should soon perk up.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Fittonia will thrive in average room temperatures between 65-80 degrees. Avoid cold drafts and direct airflow from heaters in the winter months.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Fittonia will appreciate higher humidity levels. You can boost the humidity with frequent misting, placing a humidifier nearby, or using a pebble tray. Another way to increase relative humidity is to group several humidity-loving plants together in a small area, creating a micro-climate.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed every month in spring and summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength. No fertilizer is needed during the fall and winter months when growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fittonia are non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: The creeping stems of Fittonia will naturally root into surrounding soil in the pot. In the spring, these rooted areas can be carefully cut out and potted separately to grow your collection.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your avocado tree will do best in bright light. It needs 6+ hours of direct sunlight a day to thrive indoors. A south or west window will be best, but try using a grow-light if you do not think you have enough sunlight in your home.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the soil is 50% dry. In the winter, it’s best to allow the soil to dry out more since the tree is not actively growing. Always test the soil before watering and water evenly until water runs through the drainage hole. Drain the excess water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your avocado will thrive in a humid environment. Try misting it often!

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your avocado tree will do best in warmer temperatures between 65–85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a liquid houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength once a month during the spring and summer. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil; always make sure the soil is damp before feeding your plant.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your avocado plant is toxic and not pet-friendly to many animals.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim your avocado tree back as it grows, as this will help encourage bushier growth and a stronger stem! Snip back the stems just above a leaf to remove length.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your lemon tree prefers bright light. It will thrive receiving 12 hours of direct light a day but can do well with as little as 8 hours a day. The more light it receives, the higher chance it will produce fruit. If you are keeping your tree indoors, place it next to a South facing or West facing window, or use a grow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Your lemon tree prefers to be watered when 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. Do not use a saucer outdoors or allow the plant to sit in standing water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your tree prefers a humid environment. Use a humidifier or pebble tray to increase the ambient humidity, especially during the dry winter months. Misting is not recommended with this plant since it can cause fungal issues in indoor environments that have reduced airflow.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your tree will do best in warmer temperatures between 65–85°F. Bring indoors when the temperatures dip below 40°F at night to avoid damage from freezing temperatures.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your tree every 3-4 months, during the growing season. Use a citrus fertilizer or a high potassium fertilizer to help your tree grow its fruit.

Title: TOXICITY
Description:
This tree and fruit are toxic to cats and dogs. 
Sap can cause skin irritation. The fruit alone is considered non-toxic to humans.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Keeping your tree properly pruned helps them grow out beautifully, prevent diseases and damage to branches, improve air circulation, and produce solid fruit. In February or March, prune back your tree’s overcrowded branches for a strong growing season.
If kept outdoors, bring your lemon tree inside to winterize once the temperature falls to 40 degrees at night. During this dormant time, water sparingly and do not fertilize.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your fig tree prefers direct sunlight. Place your plant in a full sun location that receives 7+ hours of direct sunlight per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot. Do not use a saucer outdoors or allow the plant to sit in standing water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Average household humidity is fine for most areas of the US

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant is hardy in zones 7-9. Bring indoors when the temperatures dip below 20°F. Plants can be damaged when temperatures drop below 15°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once during the spring and once during the fall with a balanced water soluble fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested. Sap can cause skin irritation. The fruit alone is considered non toxic to humans.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
If keeping this plant outdoors, bring your fig tree inside to winterize once the temperature falls to 20 degrees at night. During this dormant time, water sparingly and do not fertilize. This self pollinating plant will fruit in the fall if care requirements are met. 
Your fig tree’s fruit will ripen on the tree. Be sure to harvest ripe fruit before they drop to avoid messy ripe fruit falling to the ground.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your olive tree prefers direct sunlight. Place your plant in a full sun location that receives 6+ hours of direct sunlight per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 25% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot. Do not use a saucer outdoors or allow the plant to sit in standing water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Average household humidity is fine for most areas of the US.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant cannot survive winter throughout most of the US. Bring indoors when the temperatures dip below 40°F. Plants can be damaged when temperatures drop below 30°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed twice a year during the spring and summer growing season with a balanced water soluble fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your olive tree is considered nontoxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: The olive tree needs a 2 month period of dormancy during the winter with temperatures between 40-50°F to help it produce flowers and fruit. This is also known as vernalization. Keep the plant in a bright spot indoors, water sparingly, and do not fertilize during this dormant period. This self pollinating plant can fruit in summer & fall after the third year if care requirements are met.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your orange tree prefers bright light. It will thrive receiving 12 hours of direct light a day but can do well with as little as 8 hours a day. The more light it receives, the higher chance it will produce fruit. If you are keeping your tree indoors, ensure that it gets enough exposure to light, or be sure to use a grow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Your orange tree prefers to be watered when 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your tree prefers a humid environment. Make use of a humidifier or pebble tray to increase the ambient humidity. Misting is not recommended since it can cause fungal issues in indoor environments that have reduced airflow

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your tree will do best in warmer temperatures between 65–80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: During the growing season starting early spring and into summer, fertilize your tree once a month. A high potassium fertilizer will help your tree grow its fruit.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The fruit and leaves of these trees are toxic to cats and dogs.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Keeping your tree properly pruned helps them grow out beautifully, prevent diseases and damage to branches, improve air circulation, and produce solid fruit. In February or March, prune back your tree’s overcrowded branches for a strong growing season.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your lemon tree prefers bright light. It will thrive receiving 12 hours of direct light a day but can do well with as little as 8 hours a day. The more light it receives, the higher chance it will produce fruit. If you are keeping your tree indoors, place it next to a South facing or West facing window, or use a grow light.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your tree prefers a humid environment. Use a humidifier or pebble tray to increase the ambient humidity, especially during the dry winter months. Misting is not recommended with this plant since it can cause fungal issues in indoor environments that have reduced airflow.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your tree will do best in warmer temperatures between 65–85°F. Bring indoors when the temperatures dip below 40°F at night to avoid damage from freezing temperatures.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your tree every 3-4 months, during the growing season. Use a citrus fertilizer or a high potassium fertilizer to help your tree grow its fruit.

Title: TOXICITY
Description:
This tree and fruit are toxic to cats and dogs. 
Sap can cause skin irritation. The fruit alone is considered non-toxic to humans.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Keeping your tree properly pruned helps them grow out beautifully, prevent diseases and damage to branches, improve air circulation, and produce solid fruit. In February or March, prune back your tree’s overcrowded branches for a strong growing season.
If kept outdoors, bring your lemon tree inside to winterize once the temperature falls to 40 degrees at night. During this dormant time, water sparingly and do not fertilize.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Outdoors, the fuchsia plant thrives in a bright but shaded area. It can tolerate a few hours of morning sun, but avoid exposure to direct sun in the afternoon. As an indoor plant, keep your fuchsia in bright indirect sunlight.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your fuchsia when the soil volume is 25% dry. Water thoroughly and discard any excess water that accumulates in the saucer. Water more sparingly in the winter.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Fuchsias enjoy high humidity. Place a humidifier nearby or use a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The fuchsia plant enjoys temperatures between 55-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your fuchsia plant once per month beginning in the early spring through the summer and early fall. Once the plant begins to bud, you can switch over to “bloom” formula fertilizers. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter seasons when growth slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Fuchsias are non toxic to humans and pets

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: The fuchsia plant is susceptible to pests, such as aphids or spider mites. Check your plant regularly for any signs of pests. Infestations may be treated withInsecticidal SoaporNeem Oilto help keep pests at bay, following the directions on the label.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Gardenia prefers partial shade, with 4-6 hours of direct sun per day. The soft morning sun is best, so an east-facing exposure is best. Avoid exposure to the harsh afternoon sunlight, which can scorch the delicate blooms. Your Gardenia can also thrive in areas with light shade throughout the day.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Gardenia with 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water slowly, allowing it to absorb into the soil until it begins to drip out of the drainage hole. Do not use a saucer outdoors or allow the pot to sit in standing water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: For most areas of the US, your Gardenia will not require added humidity in an outdoor environment. For desert regions, mist your Gardenia frequently or use a pebble tray to boost humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Gardenias grow best in temperatures above 60°F. The foliage can be damaged at temperatures below 45°F. We recommend keeping your Gardenia indoors in a bright spot until night temperatures are consistently above 55°F. In very hot weather, the plant may pause its flowering.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Gardenia once per month in the spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer. We recommend an acidifying fertilizer, like one formulated for Azalea or Camellia.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Gardenia is considered mildly toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: For the most prolific blooming year after year, provide a cold period for your Gardenia. Also known as vernalization, a cold period signals the plant to begin winter dormancy. Prolonged exposure to outdoor autumn temperatures below 55°F will do the trick. Bring your plant indoors once night temperatures dip below 45°F. Keep the plant in a bright spot, water sparingly, and do not fertilize. Your Gardenia will not grow quickly, if at all, over the winter. Begin fertilizing it again in the early spring and move it outdoors once temperatures stay above 55°F.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Geo Plant prefers bright indirect light. Avoid extended exposure to direct sunlight which may cause its leaves to scorch.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil until it drips out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Geo Plant prefers higher than average household humidity. Add a pebble tray, group plants to create a humid microclimate, or place a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Geo Plant prefers temperatures between 60-75°F. Keep away from drafts and air vents, especially during the winter months.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once per month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Do not apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Keep the large, shiny leaves free of dust and debris by occasionally wiping them down with a soft cloth and water. The oldest leaves may yellow as the plant produces new growth. This is normal, and any yellowing leaves can be removed with clean, sharp snips.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Basil will grow best in full sun, but will also do just fine indoors on a sunny windowsill or grow light. However, make sure it is receiving at least 6-8 hours of direct sun per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Do not allow the soil of your Basil to dry out completely. Water when the top 25% of soil is dry. During peak growth in the spring and summer, watering may be needed every day.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Basil will do best in temperatures between 60-90 degrees. Basil is sensitive to the cold, so make sure the temperature does not dip below 55 degrees.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: If kept indoors, mist a few times per week.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Basil with a fertilizer for garden plants 1-2 times a month during spring and summer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Basil is non-toxic. However, it is meant to be eaten by humans and not pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Cut your Basil at any point to enjoy it. Simply cut off the top of the plant, and it will regrow new leaves from that point. Do not worry about harming the plant, as cutting it actually encourages new growth.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Cat Grass requires bright light to full sun. If grown indoors, place on a sunny windowsill or under a grow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Cat Grass when the top 25% of soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. Do not allow the soil of your Cat Grass to dry out completely.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Cat Grass prefers a humid environment. Mist often if grown indoors.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with a fertilizer for edible plants.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim your plant occasionally just like you would normal grass! Cat Grass is non-toxic to cats and can aid in digestion and prevent hairballs.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Catnip will grow best in full sun, but will be happy indoors on a sunny windowsill or under a grow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Do not allow the soil of your Catnip to dry out completely. Water when the top 25% of soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: If kept indoors, mist a few times per week.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Catnip will do best in temperatures between 60-90 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Catnip with an organic fertilizer for garden plants once a month.

Title: TOXICITY
Description:
Catnip is safe for cats in small amounts, but some cats may have adverse reactions especially in large amounts. If this is the first time you are giving your cat catnip, ask your vet first or start with a very small amount. All cats react differently.
According to the ASPCA, it can cause a digestive reaction. It makes some cats chill and some cats stimulated.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim your plant occasionally, this encourages new growth and keeps it fresh and healthy.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Chamomile plant requires 6-8 hours of bright light to full sun per day. If grown indoors, place on a sunny windowsill or under a grow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Chamomile plant when the soil is completely dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Chamomile plant prefers a humid environment. Mist often if grown indoors.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with a fertilizer for edible plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Chamomile is toxic to pets. They are meant to be eaten by humans and not pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Cut the blooms off your Chamomile Plant to use them in things like teas and oils.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Chives will grow best in full sun, but will be happy indoors on a sunny windowsill or under a grow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Do not allow the soil of your Chives to dry out completely. Water when the top 25% of soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: If kept indoors, mist a few times per week.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Chives will do best in temperatures between 60-90 degrees but they are cold-hardy.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Chives with a fertilizer for garden plants 1-2 times a month during spring and summer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Chives are toxic to pets. They are meant to be eaten by humans and not pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Cut your Chives at any point to enjoy them. To keep your plant productive and with the best-flavored leaves, remove flowers as they form.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Cilantro Plant will grow best in full sun, but will also do grow in partial shade outdoors. If growing indoors, place on a sunny windowsill or under a growlight.

Title: WATER
Description: Do not allow the soil of your Cilantro Plant to dry out completely. Water when the top 25% of soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. During peak growth in the spring and summer, watering may be needed every day.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: If kept indoors, mist a few times per week.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Cilantro Plant will do best in temperatures between 60-90 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Cilantro Plant with a fertilizer for garden plants 1-2 times a month during spring and summer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Cilantro is non-toxic. However, it is meant to be eaten by humans and not pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Cut your Cilantro at any point to enjoy it. Simply cut off the top of the plant, and it will regrow new leaves from that point. Do not worry about harming the plant, as cutting it actually encourages new growth.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Lavender plant requires 6-8 hours of bright light to full sun per day. If grown indoors, place on a sunny windowsill or under a grow light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Lavender plant when the soil is completely dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Lavender plant prefers a humid environment. Mist often if grown indoors.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with a fertilizer for edible plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Please note: Lavender is toxic to cats and dogs.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Cut your Lavender at any point to enjoy it. Cut from the top of the plant. New leaves will grow from that point. Do not worry about harming the plant, as trimming encourages new growth. When grown indoors, Lavender may not produce flowers, but you can use the leaves of the plant to flavor and add aroma to dishes just as you would the flowers. Please note: Lavender is toxic to cats and dogs.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your lavender in bright light. You can find this in an unobstructed southern or western window that receives 6+ hours of direct light a day. During the warmer months, your lavender can be placed outside.

Title: WATER
Description: Water only when 100% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly until you see if flow out of the drainage hole. Always discard any excess water in the saucer to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your lavender does well in average household humidity. However, if the air is very dry it will appreciate the occasional misting, pebble tray, or humidifier.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your lavender will do best in temperatures between 60-90°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Lavender with a fertilizer for garden plants 1-2 times a month during spring and summer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Edible plants for human consumption. Toxic to pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Cut lavender flowers or leaves at any point to enjoy the scent of the plant. Simply cut off the end portion of the stems. Don’t worry about harming the plant, as cutting will actually encourage new growth!
When grown indoors in indoor lighting, lavender may not produce flowers. You can use the leaves of the plant to add flavor and aroma to dishes, just as the flowers would.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Lemon Balm will grow best in full sun, but will also do just fine indoors on a sunny windowsill or grow light. However, make sure it is receiving at least 6-8 hours of direct sun per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Do not allow the soil of your Lemon Balm Plant to dry out completely. Water when the top 25% of soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. During peak growth in the spring and summer, watering may be needed every day.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Lemon Balm Plant appreciates higher humidity. If kept outdoors, no extra humidity is needed, but if kept indoors, mist a few times a week.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Lemon Balm Plant will do best in temperatures between 60–90 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Lemon Balm Plant with a fertilizer for garden plants 1–2 times per month during spring and summer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Lemon Balm is non-toxic. However, it is meant to be eaten by humans and not pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Cut your Lemon Balm at any point to enjoy it. Simply cut leaves from the top of the plant, and new growth will emerge from that point. Do not worry about harming the plant, as cutting it actually encourages new growth. Try not to let it flower — if you do see flowers, cut them off right away to keep your plant producing new leaves.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Lemongrass will grow best in full sun, but will also do just fine indoors on a sunny windowsill or grow light. However, make sure it is receiving at least 6-8 hours of direct sun per day.

Title: WATER
Description: Do not allow the soil of your Lemongrass to dry out completely. Water when the top 25-50% of soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: If kept indoors, mist your Lemongrass a few times per week.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Lemongrass will do best in temperatures between 60-90 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Lemongrass with a fertilizer for garden plants 1-2 times a month during spring and summer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Edible plants for humans, toxic to cats and dogs

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: To use, harvest the bulbous stems, where the most flavor will be. The leaves can also be used for infusing in teas or soups.

Boil Stevia leaves with tea leaves for a sweetened tea.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Hibiscus in a full sun location that receives 6 or more hours of direct sunlight per day. The Hibiscus can tolerate partial sun exposure, but flowering will be reduced. The plant will not produce flowers in a fully shaded location.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot. Do not use a saucer outdoors or allow the plant to sit in standing water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Average outdoor humidity is fine for most area of the US.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Keep indoors in a bright spot until outdoor temperatures remain above 50°F. Foliage can be damaged at temperatures below 45°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed every two weeks in the spring and summer with a balanced water-soluble fertilizer. For maximum flowering, use a bloom-boosting fertilizer that is high in phosphorus.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Hibiscus is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Hibiscus cannot survive winter throughout most of the US. Bring indoors when the temperatures dip below 50°F. Your plant will not grow much indoors, so water sparingly and do not fertilize over the winter. The plant can be moved outdoors when temperatures warm in the spring.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Homalomena Emerald Gem likes bright indirect light. They can tolerate lower light, but growth may slow significantly. If kept in direct sunlight, the foliage may burn.

Title: WATER
Description: Allow the top 50% of the soil of your Homalomena to dry out between watering. They do not like soggy soil, but also do not like to dry out for extended periods of time.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Homalomena will do well in average household  humidity, but will appreciate added humidity from misting or adding a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Homalomena is sensitive to temperatures below 65 degrees. Keep it in an area with temperatures between 65-85 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Homalomena Emerald Green once a month during spring and summer with a general houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Homalomena is toxic to animals and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: You may notice bottom leaves occasionally yellow and die. Not to worry–this is normal. You can cut them off using clean, sharp shears. If this is happening rapidly, it can indicate that your plant is cold, is staying too wet, or is staying too dry.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Hoya will thrive in medium to bright indirect light.  It can tolerate lower light but will likely produce flowers if placed in brighter light. The more light it receives, the more vibrant the foliage and the more flowers it will produce.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Hoya when the pot becomes completely dry.  Water thoroughly until water flows from the drainage hole on the bottom of the pot. Discard any excess water in the saucer. If your Hoya begins to drop its leaves, most likely it is being watered too much. Hoyas require less water in the winter months.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Hoya Plant will do just fine in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal room temperature for your Hoya is between 60-85 degrees. If the temperature falls below 55 degrees, it will stop growing. Avoid drafts and direct air from heating and cooling vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer at half strength once every month during the spring and summer. There is no need to feed your plant in the winter when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer make sure the soil is damp. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Hoya Plants are non-poisonous to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When Hoya plants mature, they will produce clusters of star-shaped flowers from their tendrils. Do not remove the spent flower stems or tendrils after your Hoya blooms–it will produce flowers on those stems again the next time it blooms. Also, do not move the Hoya after it begins to develop new flower buds. Moving the Hoya could disturb it and cause it to drop the buds before they open.

Title: LIGHT

Title: WATER

Title: HUMIDITY

Description: Hoyas do well in temperatures between 60-85°F.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Hoyas are nontoxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Your Hoya will put out long tendrils that grow new leaves and flowers so you can leave them be. They like to attach to trees and other structures in the wild. You can train these on a stake, trellis, or sometimes it will attach to something nearby.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Hoya Heart prefers bright indirect light but can maintain in lower lighting. Be careful not to expose it to prolonged direct sun as it can scorch the leaves.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Hoyas are considered non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Keep your Hoya looking its best bydustingits adorable heart-shaped leaf.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Hoya Krohniana in indirect bright light. It can maintain in lower lighting, but growth will be slow and it most likely will not flower. Too much light can burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Hoya when the soil is 100% dry. Water thoroughly and discard any excess water to avoid root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: The Hoya Krohniana does well in average household humidity but appreciates the occasional misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal room temperature for your Hoya is between 60-85°F. If the temperature falls below 55°F, it will stop growing. Avoid drafts and direct air from heating and cooling vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer at half strength once every month during the spring and summer. There is no need to feed your plant in the winter when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer make sure the soil is damp. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Hoyas are non-toxic to humans and pets

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When Hoya plants mature, they will produce clusters of star-shaped flowers from their tendrils. Do not remove the spent flower stems or tendrils after your Hoya blooms–it will produce flowers on those stems again the next time it blooms. Also, do not move the Hoya after it begins to develop new flower buds. Moving the Hoya could disturb it and cause it to drop the buds before they open.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Hoya will thrive in medium to bright indirect light. It can tolerate lower light but will likely produce flowers if placed in brighter light. The more light it receives, the more vibrant the foliage and the more flowers it will produce.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when soil volume is 100% dry. Water thoroughly until you see it flow out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your plant does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind added humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Hoyas do well in temperatures between 60-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer at half strength once every month during the spring and summer. There is no need to feed your plant in the winter when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer make sure the soil is damp. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Hoya Plants are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When Hoya plants mature, they will produce clusters of star-shaped flowers. Do not remove the spent flower stems after your Hoya blooms–it can produce flowers on those stems again the next time it blooms. Also, do not move the Hoya after it begins to develop new flower buds. Moving the Hoya could disturb it and cause it to drop the buds before they open.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your hoya in low to indirect light. The more light the plant receives, the faster it will grow and encourage the plant to bloom.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when soil volume is 100% dry. Water thoroughly until you see it flow out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your plant does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind added humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Hoyas do well in temperatures between 60-85°F.

Title: FOOD

There is no need to feed your plant in the winter when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer make sure the soil is damp. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Hoya Plants are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Description: When Hoya plants mature, they will produce clusters of star-shaped flowers from their tendrils. Do not remove the spent flower stems or tendrils after your Hoya blooms–it will produce flowers on those stems again the next time it blooms. Also, do not move the Hoya after it begins to develop new flower buds. Moving the Hoya could disturb it and cause it to drop the buds before they open.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Hoya will thrive in medium to bright indirect light.  It can tolerate lower light but will likely produce flowers if placed in brighter light. The more light it receives, the more vibrant the foliage and the more flowers it will produce.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Hoya when the pot becomes completely dry and even let the leaves wrinkle up a bit. Water thoroughly until water flows from the drainage hole on the bottom of the pot. Discard any excess water in the saucer. If your Hoya begins to drop its leaves, most likely it is being watered too much. Hoyas require less water in the winter months.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Hoya Plant will do just fine in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal temperature for your Hoya is between 60-85 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Use a general-purpose liquid houseplant fertilizer at half strength once every month during the spring and summer. There is no need to feed your plant in the winter when growth naturally slows. Before applying any form of fertilizer make sure the soil is damp. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil, this can cause fertilizer burn.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Hoya Pachyclada are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: When Hoya plants mature, they will produce clusters of star-shaped flowers. Do not remove the spent flower stems after your Hoya blooms–it will produce flowers on those stems again the next time it blooms. Also, do not move the Hoya after it begins to develop new flower buds. Moving the Hoya could disturb it and cause it to drop the buds before they open.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Hoya Plant will do fine in average household humidity but will appreciate added humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The ideal room temperature for your Hoya is between 60-85 degrees. If the temperature falls below 55 degrees, it will stop growing. Avoid drafts and direct air from heating and cooling vents.

Moving the Hoya could disturb it and cause it to drop the buds before they open.

Title: WATER
