Title: TOXICITY
Description: Philodendrons are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: This plant is easily propagated through cuttings to make new plants or help fill out the mother plants. Since these are climbers, you can add plant stakes or a moss pole to encourage larger leaf growth.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Philodendron Velvet can adapt to lower light conditions, however, when placed in bright indirect light, it grows faster and produces more leaves. Avoid direct sunlight–the sun will burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Philodendron when
the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry.
Water until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the
pot and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Basic household humidity is fine for your Philodendron Velvet, but higher humidity will encourage larger leaves. Your plant will benefit from an occasional misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Philodendron Velvet will grow well in temperatures between 65-80 degrees during the day and above 55 degrees at night. Keep it away from drafts, especially during the winter months.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Philodendron Velvet monthly in the spring and summer with a basic houseplant food diluted to half the recommended strength. No need to fertilize in the fall and winter months, when growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Philodendron leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will result in swelling of the lips and tongue, with stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim any dead, discolored, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems as they occur. Use clean, sharp scissors to avoid tearing or bruising the stems. Snip stems just above a leaf node. Wash the leaves frequently to prevent dust from clogging its pores. If you wish to propagate, take stem tip cuttings during the spring or early summer and place the stem in water or moist soil and they should root quite easily.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Philodendron White Knight can survive in low light conditions, but grows faster and produces more white variegation in bright indirect light. The plant can only tolerate some direct sun in the morning; extended periods of direct light can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Philodendron White Knight when the soil is 50-75% dry. Water thoroughly until water comes out of the drainage holes, and be sure to empty the saucer of any excess water. This plant is sensitive to overwatering. If the soil remains constantly wet, the roots will rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Basic household humidity is fine for your Philodendron White Knight but higher humidity encourages larger leaves. Your plant will benefit from a pebble tray or adding a humidifier.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Philodendron White Knight will grow well in temperatures between 65-80°F. Keep away from drafts, especially during the winter months.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Philodendron White Knight monthly in the spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant. Always fertilize on moist soil, never dry as it can burn the roots.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, or damaged leaves using clean, sharp scissors. As the plant ages, the older leaves will naturally turn yellow or brown and fall off. Your Philodendron White Knight is a vining plant, so consider providing a trellis or moss pole for it to climb on.

Title: LIGHT
Description:
Your Philodendron prefers medium
to bright indirect light. It can adapt
to low light, but growth may slow.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Philodendron when the top 50%-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Philodendron Xanadu will tolerate the level of humidity found in most homes, but high humidity promotes lush growth and shiny foliage, so it is a good idea to mist the plant regularly.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Philodendron Xanadu likes warm temperatures above 55 degrees. Keep them away from drafts and open doors, especially during the winter.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize monthly during the spring and summer with a balanced, water-soluble fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil, always make sure soil is damp before applying plant food.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Philodendron Xanadu leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will result in swelling of the lips and tongue, and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Yellow leaves on your Xanadu occur naturally as new growth comes in or if it is acclimating to a new spot in your home. Remove these yellow dead or dying leaves regularly by snapping them off where the leaf stem touches the primary stem or the soil surface. It is also a good idea to periodically look between the dense foliage and remove the dried leaf husks left behind when a new leaf is produced. Regularly clearing away this dead organic material prevents mold, fungus, and worst of all Fungus Gnats.

Title: LIGHT
Description:
Your Pilea prefers bright, indirect
light. Direct sun may burn the
leaves. In order to prevent your Pilea from growing lopsided, rotate it at least 2-3 times a week since it grows towards the sun. This plant can adapt to lower light areas, but the leaves will turn a darker green and the plant will spread out more.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Pilea when the top 75%
of the soil is dry. Water until liquid
flows through the drainage hole at
the bottom of the pot and discard
any water that has accumulated in
the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Pilea  does not require extra humidity, but a generous misting every now and again will be appreciated.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Pilea will be happiest in normal household temperatures between 65-75 degrees. However, make sure that your Pilea does not sit near the heating vents in the winter, as it may drop its leaves.

Title: FOOD
Description:
Feed once a month during the
spring and summer with a liquid
fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Pilea are generally non-toxic for humans and pets. However, when ingested in very large quantities, they can cause a mild digestive reaction.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you notice white spots on your Pilea, they are most likely caused by salts and chemicals in your water. If you do not have a filtration system, leaving the tap water in an open container overnight before watering can help remove some of the chemicals.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pilea Baby Tears will be happiest in medium to bright light. Keep out of the direct sun–it will burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Pilea when the top 75%
of the soil is dry. Water until liquid
flows through the drainage hole at
the bottom of the pot and discard
any water that has accumulated in
the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Pilea Baby Tears does not require extra humidity, but a generous misting every now and again will be appreciated.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Pilea Baby Tears prefers temperatures between 55-80 degrees during the day and should not get colder than 55 degrees at night.

Title: FOOD
Description:
Feed once a month during the
spring and summer with a liquid
fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Pilea Baby Tears is non-toxic to pets and children.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
If you notice white spots on your
Pilea, they are most likely caused
by salts and chemicals in your tap
water. If you do not have a filtration
system, leaving the tap water in an
open container overnight before
watering can help remove some
of the chemicals by
evaporation.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pilea prefers bright to medium indirect light. It can tolerate low light, but it may become leggy and dull. Avoid extended exposure to direct sunlight, which can scorch its leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil until it drips out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Pilea prefers higher than average household humidity. Add a pebble tray, group plants to create a humid microclimate, or place a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Pilea prefers temperatures between 60° – 80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once per month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Do not apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Pilea plants benefit from an occasional trim, which will encourage them to stay full and bushy. Cuttings can easily be rooted in moist soil to grow your collection or share with friends. If you notice the coloration becoming dull, try moving the plant to a spot with brighter, indirect light.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pilea prefers bright to medium indirect light. It can tolerate low light, but it may become leggy and lose its vibrant color. Avoid extended exposure to direct sunlight, which can scorch its leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil until it drips out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Pilea prefers higher than average household humidity. Add a pebble tray, group plants to create a humid microclimate, or place a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant prefers temperatures between 60-80°F. Keep it away from drafty windows and air vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once per month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Do not apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Pilea plants benefit from an occasional trim, which will encourage them to stay full and bushy. Cuttings can easily be rooted in moist soil to grow your collection or share with friends. If you notice the coloration becoming dull, try moving the plant to a spot with brighter, indirect light.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Aralia Bianca will do best in bright indirect light, but will also tolerate low to medium light conditions.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water when 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the
bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Aralia Bianca will love a boost in humidity from time to time but will tolerate average household humidity. If the air gets too dry in the winter, your plant may start to drop leaves. Increase humidity by placing a humidifier nearby or using a pebble tray. Another way to increase relative humidity is to group several humidity-loving plants together in a small area, creating a micro-climate.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Average indoor temperatures are great for your Aralia Bianca–between 60-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every other month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: False Threadleaf Aralia is toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: False Threadleaf Aralia plants are sensitive to being moved too often–if you have to move it around in your home, do so gradually. Any sudden changes can shock it and cause leaves to drop.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Aralia Bianca will do best in bright indirect light, but will also tolerate low to medium light conditions.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the top 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Like other popular indoor plants, your Threadleaf Aralia appreciates humidity. Feel free to place a humidifier nearby or use a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The Threadleaf Aralia is comfortable in temperatures between 65 and 85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every other month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: False Threadleaf Aralia plants are sensitive to being moved. If you have to move your plant around, do so gradually. Any sudden changes can cause leaves to drop.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Poinsettias love bright but indirect sunlight. An eastern window is ideal, or a few feet back from a southern or western window. Watch out for pale bleached leaves as this is a sign your plant is getting too much direct sun.

Title: WATER
Description: You should water your poinsettia when the top 50% of soil is dry. Water slowly until you see water begin to trickle out of the pot’s drainage hole, and make sure you let excess water fully drain out. Discard any excess water after a few minutes.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Poinsettias enjoy humidity between 50% – 75% ambient humidity. You can boost humidity by misting, adding a pebble tray, or placing a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Poinsettia flowers appreciate daytime temperatures between 65-75° F and nighttime temperatures of 55-60° F. Keep your poinsettia away from drafty windows or doors, and any open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: You can give your poinsettia a boost with fertilizer for flowering plants. Fertilize once a month after the plant begins growing again in the spring and throughout the growing season and into the fall. No fertilizer is needed during the winter months.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Toxic only if ingested in very high amounts to pets and humans. The sap can be irritating to the mouth and stomach if ingested, sometimes causing vomiting. The sap may also cause a very mild allergic skin reaction in some people.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: To encourage your plant to take on a full, bushy shape, prune the stems back in spring and allow the plant to flush out new growth. To encourage the plant to rebloom, ensure the plant receives complete darkness for 14 hours a day for a span of 8 weeks, beginning in mid to late September. This signals the plant to begin producing flower buds and colorful bracts in time for the holiday season.

Title: LIGHT
Description:
Your Pigtail Palm prefers bright
indirect light to full sun.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Pigtail Palm when
the soil is completely dry. Water
until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the
pot and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: As with most succulents, your Pigtail Palm will thrive in dry conditions. The drier the air, the better!

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Protect your palm from cold drafts from windows, air conditioning vents, or doors. This plant prefers normal room temperatures between 60-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer only once in the spring and once in the summer. Any more than that and your Pigtail Palm may develop brown tips on the leaves.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Completely non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Your Pigtail Palm leaves are sensitive to injury and tend to get dark at the ends. Cutting back the tips of the leaves is a good way to preserve the appearance of the plant. The key is to use a pair of sharp scissors to cut off just the discolored parts.

Title: LIGHT
Description: The ponytail palm thrives with bright light and can tolerate direct sun all day. It’s happy to live outdoors in the summer where it can soak up the sun! Bring it back indoors when the night temperatures start to dip.

Title: WATER
Description: Let the soil volume dry 100% between waterings. Water thoroughly to encourage a healthy root system and discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: As with most succulents, your Ponytail Palm will thrive in dry conditions. The drier the air, the better!

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant prefers normal room temperatures between 60-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: For best results, use a general houseplant fertilizer only once in the spring and once in the summer. Any more than that and your Ponytail Palm may develop brown tips on the leaves.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Non-toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Your Ponytail Palm leaves are sensitive to injury and tend to get dark at the ends. Cutting back the tips of the leaves is a good way to preserve the appearance of the plant. The key is to use a sharp scissors to cut off just the discolored parts.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pothos prefers indirect bright light. It can tolerate lower light, but growth will slow. Avoid prolonged exposure to direct light, which can scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Pothoswhen 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Pothos will do well in average household humidity, but will thrive with a boost of humidity. Try adding a pebble tray, grouping with other plants, or placing a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Pothos prefers temperatures between 65-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once per month in spring through fall with anall-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants, diluted to half strength. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, or damaged leaves and stems as they occur with clean,sharp scissors. Snipping stems just above a leaf node will encourage bushy and fuller growth. Stems that are removed can be easily propagated in water.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Cebu Blue Pothos can survive in low light, but grows faster in medium to bright indirect light. Direct sunlight can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Pothos when the top 50-75% of the soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer. These plants can tolerate an occasional missed watering.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Pothos will do well in low humidity environments, but will thrive with a bit more humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Cebu Blue Pothos prefers average to warm temperatures between 65-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed every 1-2 months in the spring and summer with general-purpose indoor plant fertilizer. Before applying fertilizer in any form make sure the soil is damp.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Pothos are mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim any dead, discolored, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems as they occur. Use clean, sharp scissors to avoid tearing or bruising the stems. If you wish to keep your plant full and bushy, trim the longer vines every few months.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pothos prefers indirect bright light. It can tolerate lower light, but growth will slow and the colors may fade. Direct light can scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant does well in average household humidity but appreciates an occasional boost of humidity. Try adding a pebble tray, grouping it with other plants, or placing a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your plant prefers temperatures between 65°-85°F. Avoid cold drafty areas and open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month in the spring and summer with general-purpose houseplant fertilizer diluted to half-strength. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Pothos is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, or damaged leaves and stems as they occur with clean, sharp scissors. Snipping stems just above a leaf node will encourage bushy and fuller growth. Stems that are removed can be easily propagated in water.

Title: LIGHT
Description:
Your Pothos is adaptable. It prefers
bright, indirect light, but will
tolerate medium and low light. The variegation will be more pronounced in brighter light. Your Pothos will not do well in direct sunlight–the sunlight can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Pothos when the top
50% of the soil is dry. Water until
liquid flows through the drainage
hole at the bottom of the pot
and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer. Look out for yellow leaves, they are a symptom of too much water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant will do well in environments with low humidity but will thrive in a location that is more humid, such as a bathroom or kitchen. Brown leaf tips may indicate the air is too dry.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Hawaiian Pothos prefers average to warm temperatures of 65-85 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed monthly or every other month in the spring and summer with a general-purpose indoor plant fertilizer. Before applying any fertilizer in any form make sure the soil is damp.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Pothos are mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim any dead, discolored, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems as they occur. Use clean, sharp scissors to avoid tearing or bruising the stems. Snip stems just above a leaf node; new growth will emerge from this cut.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Jade Pothos is able to adapt to lower light but thrives in bright, indirect light year-round. Harsh, direct sunlight will scorch the leaves, while not enough light will cause the leaves to become discolored and smaller in size.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Pothos when the top
50% of the soil is dry. Water until
liquid flows through the drainage
hole at the bottom of the pot
and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Jade Pothos does best in a slightly more humid environment, such as a bathroom or kitchen. Brown leaf tips may indicate the air is too dry.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Jade Pothos prefer temperatures of 65-85 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed monthly or every other month in the spring and summer with a general-purpose indoor plant fertilizer. Before applying any fertilizer in any form make sure the soil is damp.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Jade Pothos is mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Feel free to trim your Jade Pothos regularly. Trim any dead, discolored, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems as they occur. Use clean, sharp scissors to avoid tearing or bruising the stems. Snip stems just above a leaf node; new growth will emerge from this cut.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pothos prefers indirect bright light. It can tolerate lower light, but growth will slow and the colors may fade. Direct light can scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant does well in average household humidity but appreciates an occasional boost of humidity. Try adding a pebble tray, grouping it with other plants, or placing a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your plant prefers temperatures between 65°-85°F. Avoid cold drafty areas and open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month in the spring and summer with general-purpose houseplant fertilizer diluted to half-strength. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Pothos is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, or damaged leaves and stems as they occur with clean, sharp scissors. Snipping stems just above a leaf node will encourage bushy and fuller growth. Stems that are removed can be easily propagated in water.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Neon Pothos is able to adapt to lower light but thrives in bright, indirect light year-round. Harsh, direct sunlight will scorch the leaves, while too little light will cause the leaves to become a pale green and smaller in size.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Pothos when the top
50% of the soil is dry. Water until
liquid flows through the drainage
hole at the bottom of the pot
and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer. Look out for drooping yellow leaves, they are a symptom of too much water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your bathroom or kitchen would be a great choice for your Neon Pothos because it does best in a slightly more humid environment. Brown leaf tips may indicate the air is too dry.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Neon Pothos prefer average to warm temperatures of 65-85 degrees during the day and not below 60 degrees at night.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed monthly or every other month in the spring and summer with a general-purpose indoor plant fertilizer. Before applying any fertilizer in any form make sure the soil is damp prior to application.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Pothos is mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Feel free to trim your Neon Pothos regularly. This encourages the plant to develop more side-shoots and reduces the demand for the plant to develop a larger root system while in a confined container.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pothos prefers indirect bright light. It can tolerate lower light, but growth will slow and the colors may fade. Direct light can scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant does well in average household humidity but appreciates an occasional boost of humidity. Try adding a pebble tray, grouping it with other plants, or placing a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your plant prefers temperatures between 65°-85°F. Avoid cold drafty areas and open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month in the spring and summer with general-purpose houseplant fertilizer diluted to half-strength. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Pothos is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, or damaged leaves and stems as they occur with clean, sharp scissors. Snipping stems just above a leaf node will encourage bushy and fuller growth. Stems that are removed can be easily propagated in water.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Pearls N Joy Pothos grows best in medium and high light areas but will tolerate low light. The variegation will be more pronounced in higher light. Direct sunlight will burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Pothos when the top 75% of soil is dry. Don’t worry if you forget—it will tolerate an occasional missed watering! Look out for yellow leaves, they are a symptom of too much water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant will do well in low humidity environments but will thrive with a bit more humidity. Mist often. Brown leaf tips may indicate the air is too dry.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Pearls N Joy Pothos prefers average to warm temperatures, 65-85 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once a month with an all-purpose fertilizer for houseplants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Pothos is mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems as they occur. Use clean, sharp scissors to avoid tearing or bruising the stems. Snip stems just above a leaf node – new growth will emerge from this cut.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Keep your Silver Satin Pothos in indirect bright light. Too little light will cause the silver color to fade, but too much light will burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: These plants like to be mostly dry between waterings due to their thick leaves. Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Always water through and discard any excess water in the saucer to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Silver Satin Pothos does well in average household humidity. However, if the air is very dry it will appreciate the occasional misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Silver Satin Pothos prefer average to warm temperatures of 65-85°F. Avoid cold drafty areas and open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed monthly in the spring through fall with a general-purpose indoor plant fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The SIlver Satin Pothos is toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems as they occur with clean, sharp scissors. Snip stems just above a leaf node; new growth will emerge from this cut and trimming close to the node will also prevent an ugly stub at the site. Use sharp pruning shears to avoid tearing the stems.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Prayer Plant prefers bright, indirect light. Direct sun can cause the leaves to fade and scorch.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the soil volume is 25% dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole and discard any that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant prefers above-average humidity. Use a pebble tray, place a humidifier nearby, or mist often.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Prayer Plants prefer temperatures between 68° – 85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: You can prune your Prayer Plant to encourage full, vigorous growth. Use a sterilized pair of sharp scissors and clip the stems right above a leaf node. You’ll soon notice new growth emerging directly below the cut area.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Prayer Plant prefers bright, indirect light. Direct sun can cause the leaves to fade and scorch.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the soil volume is 25% dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole and discard any that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant prefers above-average humidity. Use a pebble tray, place a humidifier nearby, or mist often.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Prayer Plants prefer temperatures between 68° – 85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: You can prune your Prayer Plant to encourage full, vigorous growth. Use a sterilized pair of sharp scissors and clip the stems right above a leaf node. You’ll soon notice new growth emerging directly below the cut area.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Prayer Plant prefers bright, indirect light. Direct sun can cause the leaves to fade and scorch.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the soil volume is 25% dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole and discard any that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant prefers above-average humidity. Use a pebble tray, place a humidifier nearby, or mist often.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Prayer Plants prefer temperatures between 68° – 85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: You can prune your Prayer Plant to encourage full, vigorous growth. Use a sterilized pair of sharp scissors and clip the stems right above a leaf node. You’ll soon notice new growth emerging directly below the cut area.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your purple passion plant prefers moderate to bright indirect light.

Title: WATER
Description: You allow 25% of the soil volume to dry before watering. When watering, try not to get the leaves wet as the hairs can trap moisture and cause the leaves to become waterlogged.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your purple passion plant prefers a fairly humid environment. Avoid misting though, as it does not like to get water on the leaves. Instead, add a humidifier nearby or create a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your purple passion plant prefers average indoor temperatures of 60–70°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your plant once a month during spring and summer with an all-purpose liquid fertilizer diluted to half strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Purple passion plants are considered non-toxic for pets and humans.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If the plant starts to flower, that’s a sign it has reached maturity and you may want to start collecting cuttings.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Purple Waffle prefers bright indirect light, but not direct sun. In less light, it may lose some of the rich purple coloring.

Title: WATER
Description: Your Purple Waffle prefers consistently moist soil. Allow the water to flow freely from the drainage holes on the bottom of the pot. Always empty the saucer of any water.  Purple Waffle does not like its roots to be sitting in water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Purple Waffle loves to be misted, feel free to do this daily, especially in the winter when the air is very dry. Not only does misting provide humidity, it also keeps pests away.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Purple Waffle plant can grow in temperatures between 55-80 degrees, but they do prefer a consistent temperature.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize your Purple Waffle once a month in the spring and summer with a general indoor plant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength. No need to feed in the fall or winter, when plant growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Purple Waffle is non-toxic to pets and humans.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you prefer a bushier plant, pinch the tips of your waffle plant whenever the plant shoots up new growth. Pinch the stems just above a leaf, stem or bud.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Rhaphidophora prefers bright, indirect light. It can survive in medium light conditions but may stop growing or produce smaller leaves. Do not put it in full, direct sunlight—the sun will burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Rhaphidophora when
the top 50-75% of the soil is dry.
Water until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the
pot and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Basic household humidity is fine for your Rhaphidophora, but higher humidity encourages larger leaves. Your plant will benefit from the occasional misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Rhaphidophora will grow best in temperatures between 70-80 degrees. Keep it away from drafts, especially during the winter months.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Rhaphidophora leaves are toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will result in swelling of the lips and tongue, and stomach irritation with possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description:
Regularly remove any dead
leaves from the plant to encourage
healthy new growth. Cut leaves
close to the stem with clean,
sharp shears. Wash the leaves
frequently to prevent dust from
clogging the pores.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Rose in a full sun location that receives 6 or more hours of direct sunlight per day. Roses can tolerate partial sun exposure, but flowering will be reduced. The plant will not produce flowers in a fully shaded location.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot. Do not use a saucer outdoors or allow the plant to sit in standing water.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Average outdoor humidity is fine for most area of the US.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Keep indoors in a bright spot until outdoor temperatures remain above 45°F. Foliage can be damaged in below-freezing temperatures.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed every two weeks in the spring and summer with a balanced water-soluble fertilizer. For maximum flowering, use a bloom-boosting fertilizer that is high in phosphorus.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Rose is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly, but watch out for the sharp thorns.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Bring your plant indoors once night temperatures dip below 35°F. Keep the plant in a bright spot, water sparingly, and do not fertilize. Your Rose will not grow quickly, if at all, over the winter. Begin fertilizing it again in the early spring and move it outdoors once temperatures stay above 45°F. If you live in USDA Zone 5 or above, you can plant your Rose in the ground. It will survive the winter and come back to life every spring for years to come!

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Sago Palm prefers bright indirect light to direct sunlight. Choose a south- or west-facing window, or supplement with a grow light to encourage growth and a deep green color.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Sago Palm when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly, allowing it to soak into the soil until it drips out of the drainage hole. Remove excess water that collects in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Sago Palms do fine in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Maintain a temperature between 65-75°F. If moved outdoors for the summer, Sago Palms don’t mind the heat but will need to be watered more frequently.

Title: FOOD
Description: Water your Sago Palm once in the spring and once in the summer. Use a general purpose houseplant fertilizer or one formulated specifically for palms, diluted to half-strength.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Sago Palms are considered highly toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Aside from bright light and occasional fertilizer, your Sago Palm doesn’t require much care. It is susceptible to root rot, especially in the fall and winter months, so take care not to overwater it. The plant naturally sheds its lower leaves as it grows. As these leaves begin to yellow, they can be removed with a sharp cutting tool.

Title: LIGHT
Description:
Your Sansevieria is adaptable. It
prefers medium to bright indirect
light, but can also tolerate lower
light as well as direct sun.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Sansevieria only when
the soil is completely dry. Water
until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the
pot and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Sansevieria will thrive in temperatures of 55-85 degrees. However, they prefer temperatures on the warmer end of that spectrum.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description:
Your Sansevieria prefers a dry
environment. No need to mist.

Title: FOOD
Description:
Feed once every six months with a
liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Sansevieria is mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Your Sansevieria is an easy, hardy plant and doesn’t require any additional care.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Snake Plant can tolerate any light level. The brighter the light, the faster it will grow. Always acclimate the plant over a few weeks if moving from indirect to direct light to avoid scorching the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water only when the soil volume is 100% dry. It’s better to err on the dry side. Water thoroughly to encourage a healthy root system and discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Sansevieria prefers a dry environment. No need to mist.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Temperatures ranging from 55-85°F are fine for your Snake Plant. Warmer temperatures encourage faster growth.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every six months with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Snake Plants are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Snake Plants reproduce by growing new plants (or ‘‘pups’’) near the base of the mother plant. To propagate your Snake Plant, carefully remove the leaves and stems of each pup once they become a few inches tall and plant them into a new pot.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Does well in indirect bright light, but can maintain in low light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when the soil volume is 100% dry. Water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water from the tray after a few minutes.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Sansevieria Cylindrica does well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Conditions ranging from 55-85°F are fine for your Sansevieria Cylindrica.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every six months with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Sansevieria Cylindrica is toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Keep your Sansevieria Cylindrica’s leaves clean by wiping them down with a damp cloth every couple of months. This removes dust to optimize photosynthesizing and discourages pests from taking up residence.

Title: LIGHT
Description:
Your Sansevieria is adaptable. It
prefers medium to bright indirect
light, but can also tolerate lower
light as well as direct sun.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Sansevieria only when
the soil is completely dry. Water
until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the
pot and discard any water that has
accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description:
Your Sansevieria prefers a dry
environment. No need to mist.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Sansevieria with thrive in average household temperatures of 55-85 degrees, but they prefer to be kept on the warmer end of the spectrum.

Title: FOOD
Description:
Feed once every six months with a
liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Sansevierias are mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Sansevierias are an easy, hardy plant and don’t require any additional care.

Title: WATER

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Sansevieria prefers a dry environment. No need to mist.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Sansevieria prefers temperatures of 55°-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every six months with a general-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Keep the leaves of your Sansevieria clean by wiping them down with a damp cloth every couple of months. Removing dust will optimize photosynthesis and discourage pests from taking up residence.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Conditions ranging from 55-85 degrees are fine for the Sansevieria Moonshine, however, they prefer warmer temperatures.

liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Sansevieria Moonshine is mildly toxic to pets and humans. Typically, ingestion will cause mouth and stomach irritation and possible vomiting.

Title: TEMPERATURE

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Keep the leaves of your Sansevieria clean by wiping them down with a damp cloth every couple of months. Removing dust will optimize photosynthesis and discourage pests from taking up residence.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Whale Fin Sansevieria will grow more in indirect light but can maintain in lower light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Whale Fin Sansevieria when the soil is 100% dry. When all the way dry, water thoroughly until you see water flow out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water after a few minutes.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Sansevierias do well in dry to average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Conditions ranging from 55-85°F are fine for the Sansevieria, however, they prefer warmer temperatures.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every six months with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Dust regularly to deter pests and keep the unique striped pattern looking its best.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Schefflera prefers bright indirect light but can tolerate medium and low light. Too much direct sunlight can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly until you see it flow out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water in the saucer to avoid root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your plant does fine in average household humidity, but won’t mind added humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Schefflera Amate prefers temperatures between 60-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with a well-balanced fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Schefflera are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you want to keep your Schefflera small in size or a specific shape, feel free to prune it at any time with sharp, clean shears. Be sure not to trim more than 30% of the plant, as any more may shock your Schefflera. Wipe the foliage down every so often to remove dust accumulation on the leaves and discourage pests.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Schefflera Arboricola prefers bright indirect light but can tolerate lower light conditions as well. Rotate your plant a half-turn once a month. As it grows, it leans towards the light, so this will keep it looking full and even.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Schefflera when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Schefflera prefers a humid environment. Boost humidity by misting often, placing a humidifier nearby, or using a pebble tray.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant prefers temperatures between 50° – 80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter months when growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Prune your Schefflera regularly to keep it small in size or neatly shaped. Use a clean pair of pruning shears and never remove more than 30% of the plant at a time—any more may shock it. Rotate your plant on a regular basis to promote even, balanced growth.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Schefflera prefers bright indirect light. It can also tolerate medium and low light, but growth will slow. Direct sun in the early morning and late afternoon is fine, but avoid exposure to the harsh midday sun which can scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil, until it flows freely through the drainage hole. Discard any excess water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Schefflera prefers a humid environment. Add a pebble tray or place a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant prefers temperatures between 50° – 80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter months when growth naturally slows.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Prune your Schefflera regularly to keep it small in size or neatly shaped. Use a clean pair of pruning shears and never remove more than 30% of the plant at a time—any more may shock it. Rotate your plant on a regular basis to promote even, balanced growth.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Keep your Silver Satin Pothos in indirect bright light. Too little light will cause the silver color to fade, but too much light will burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: These plants like to be mostly dry between waterings due to their thick leaves. Water when 75% of the soil volume is dry. Always water through and discard any excess water in the saucer to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Silver Satin Pothos does well in average household humidity. However, if the air is very dry it will appreciate the occasional misting.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Silver Satin Pothos prefer average to warm temperatures of 65-85°F. Avoid cold drafty areas and open vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed monthly in the spring through fall with a general-purpose indoor plant fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The SIlver Satin Pothos is toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems as they occur with clean, sharp scissors. Snip stems just above a leaf node; new growth will emerge from this cut and trimming close to the node will also prevent an ugly stub at the site. Use sharp pruning shears to avoid tearing the stems.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Scindapsus prefers indirect bright light. This plant can only tolerate some direct sun in the morning; extended periods of direct light can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Scindapsus when the soil volume is 50-75% dry. Water thoroughly until water comes out of the drainage holes, and be sure to empty the saucer of any excess water. These plants are sensitive to overwatering—if the soil remains constantly wet, the roots will rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Average household humidity is fine for your Scindapsus, but higher humidity encourages larger leaves. Your plants will benefit from a pebble tray or adding a humidifier.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your plant will grow well in temperatures between 65-80°F. Keep away from drafts, especially during the winter months.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Scindapsus monthly in the spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter months when the plants are dormant. Always fertilize on moist soil, never dry, as it can burn the roots.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Scindapsus are toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Scindapsus are easily propagated through cuttings to make new plants or help fill out the mother plants. Since these are climbers, you can add plant stakes or a moss pole to encourage larger leaf growth.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Scindapsus Moonlight prefers indirect bright light. This plant can only tolerate some direct sun in the morning; extended periods of direct light can burn the foliage.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Scindapsus Moonlight when the soil volume is 50-75% dry. Water thoroughly until water comes out of the drainage holes, and be sure to empty the saucer of any excess water. This plant is sensitive to overwatering—if the soil remains constantly wet, the roots will rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Average household humidity is fine for your Scindapsus Moonlight but higher humidity encourages larger leaves. Your plant will benefit from a pebble tray or adding a humidifier.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Scindapsus Moonlight will grow well in temperatures between 65-85°F. Keep away from drafts, especially during the winter months.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Scindapsus Moonlight monthly in the spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant. Always fertilize on moist soil, never dry, as it can burn the roots.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Trim out any dead, discolored, or damaged leaves using clean, sharp scissors. As the plant ages, the older leaves will naturally turn yellow or brown and fall off. This Scindapsus is easily propagated through cuttings to make new plants or help fill out the mother plant.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your sensitive plant does best in bright, direct sunlight. Give it as much light as possible, preferably from a south or west window.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your sensitive plant when 50% of the soil volume is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Sensitive Plants require high humidity to look their best. They will thrive in steamy bathrooms. You can also mist your plant often or add a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: The sensitive plant prefers an average room temperature between 65-75°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Growth of the Sensitive Plant can be enhanced with a high-potassium liquid fertilizer diluted to about half strength with water. Fertilize once a month during the growing season of spring and summer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Sensitive Plant is considered toxic to both humans and animals when ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Prune your plant regularly to keep it full and prevent it from becoming leggy. You can prune your plant any time of the year.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your spider plant can be placed in low to indirect bright light. The more light the plant receives, the bolder the stripes will be. Watch out for too much direct light and it can scorch the leaves. If you don’t have an ideal location for your Spider Plant, use aGrow Light.

Title: WATER
Description: Wateryour spider plant when 50-75% of the soil volume is dry. Dry crispy tips often point to underwatering while dark brown tips point to overwatering. Water thoroughly and discard of any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Spider Plant will do well in normal household humidity but will thrive with a bit more humidity. Brown leaf tips may indicate the air is too dry, so mist your Spider Plant regularly using aMister.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your plant prefers temperatures between 60–80° F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants such as ourAll Purpose Fertilizer (20-20-20).

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Spider Plant is non-toxic and safe for humans, dogs, and cats.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Mature spider plants will produce “spiderettes,” or “pups.” These are new plant offshoots from the mother plant that you can trim off and nurture to produce an entirely new plant. To propagate, cut off the small plant from the mother, and place the bottom end in a glass of water. You should see roots develop in 2–4 weeks. After roots develop, plant the pup in soil and water regularly. If your Spider Plant is in need of a trim, clean up your plant using clean, sharpPlant Snips.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Dragon’s Tongue prefers bright indirect light. It can adapt to lower light, but its purple coloring will fade.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Dragon’s Tongue when 25% of the soil volume is dry. Water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil until it drips out of the drainage hole. Discard any excess water that accumulates in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your plant prefers higher than average household humidity. Add a pebble tray, group plants to create a humid microclimate, or place a humidifier nearby.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: This plant prefers temperatures between 60-80°F. Keep it away from drafty windows and air vents.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once per month in the spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer for indoor plants. Do not apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered non-toxic and pet-friendly.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Dragon’s Tongue plants benefit from an occasional trim, which will encourage them to stay full and bushy. If you notice the coloration becoming dull, try moving the plant to a spot with brighter, indirect light.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Stromanthe Peacock in a warm, well-lit spot. The more bright indirect light the plant receives, the more variegation you will see on the leaves. Never expose it to direct sunlight–it will scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Stromanthe when the top 25% of soil is dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage
hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Stromathe Peacock loves a humid environment, so feel free to mist every day. Use a pebble tray or a humidifier during the winter months when the air tends to be drier. The leaves will turn brown and crispy when the air is too dry.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Stromanthe Peacock prefers temperatures between 65-80 degrees during the day and no cooler than 60 degrees at night. Avoid placing your plants near heating and air conditioning vents and fans.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once a month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for indoor plants.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: The Stromanthe Peacock is non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Turn your plant every week, as it will reach for the light. Adding humidity is key in keeping this plant healthy, thriving and full of splendid colors! Mist often or use a pebble tray.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Stromanthe Triostar prefers a well-lit spot with bright, indirect light. Though it can tolerate lower levels of light, the bright variegation will fade. Avoid direct sunlight which can burn the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water when 25-50% of the soil volume is dry. Water thoroughly and discard any excess water in the saucer. Overwatering can cause root rot. Growth naturally slows in the winter and watering frequency should be reduced.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Stromanthe prefers a humid environment. Use a pebble tray, group it with other plants, or place a humidifier nearby. If this humidity is too low, leaf edges will begin to brown.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Stromanthe prefers temperatures between 65-80°F. Avoid drafts from vents or drafty doors and windows.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Stromanthe once per month during the spring and summer with a general purpose houseplant fertilizer diluted to half-strength. Make sure the soil is damp; never apply fertilizer to dry soil.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Stromanthe Triostars are non-toxic to humans and pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Turn your plant regularly to maintain full and balanced growth, since it naturally grows towards the light. High humidity will help leaves develop with vivid coloration and large size.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Agave Geminiflora needs bright direct light for 6-8 hours a day. You can find this in an unobstructed southern or western window.

Title: WATER
Description: Water only when 100% of the soil volume is dry. This succulent-like plant does not tolerate soggy soil. Always water thoroughly and discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Agave Geminiflora does fine in household humidity and prefers drier air.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Agave Geminiflora prefers temperatures between 65-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once in the summer with a cactus/succulent fertilizer at half strength. Always fertilize on damp soil. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: You’ll notice your agave has fibrous, silvery hairs that curl back along the leaf margins. This is normal and no cause for concern. You can leave them as-is or prune them with sharp snips.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Aloe plant prefers bright indirect light to full sun. Insufficient light will cause the leaves to droop downwards. If you don’t have a location with ideal lighting for your plant, use aGrow Light!

Title: WATER
Description: Wateryour Aloe when the soil volume is 100% dry. Water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole. Discard excess water to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant does not require any extra humidity and can handle dry air.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Aloe will appreciate temperatures between 65-75°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once in the spring and once in the summer with aliquid fertilizerfor cacti and succulents.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If you place your plant in the full sun during the late spring and summer, it will most likely reward you with pink blooms. When placed outdoors, it will require a bit more water. Look out for wilting leaves—this is a result of inadequate water. Your Aloe plant is sensitive to overwatering. Soft, mushy, or brown leaves indicate your plant may be suffering from root rot.

Title: LIGHT

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Calico Kitten in direct or bright indirect light. It will not thrive if it does not receive enough sunlight.

Title: WATER
Description: Your Calico Kitten does not need to be watered as frequently as most indoor plants. Water only when the soil is completely dry, or when you notice the leaves starting to shrivel. Water thoroughly so the roots have a chance to soak up the moisture. Make sure there is no standing water left in the saucer, as this can lead to root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Calico Kitten does not require any extra humidity and enjoys dry air.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Calico Kitten will do just fine in average room temperatures between 60–80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for succulents.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: No known toxic effects have been reported.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Your plant will become pinker when grown in direct sunlight. When grown in indirect light, it will be greener and less pink.

Title: LIGHT
Description:
Your Crassula prefers bright light
and full sun.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Succulent only when the soil is completely dry. Water until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Succulent prefers a dry environment. No need to mist.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Crassula Cephalophora will do just fine in average room temperatures between 60-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once in the spring and once in the summer with a succulent fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Crassula Cephalophora is considered to be toxic to pets and humans. Ingestion may cause mouth and stomach irritation.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Over time, your Crassula will shed its lower leaves. Though this can be alarming, it is completely natural and does not mean your plant is dying.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Echeveria bright light to full sun. It will not thrive if it does not receive enough sunlight.

Title: WATER
Description:
Water your Succulent only when the soil is completely dry. Water until liquid flows through the
drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Succulent prefers a dry environment. No need to mist.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Echeveria will do just fine in average room temperatures between 60-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once in the spring and once in the summer with a succulent fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Echeveria is non-toxic according to the ASPCA.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Over time, your succulent will shed the lower leaves. Though this can be alarming, it is completely natural and does not mean your plant is dying.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Echeveria Rosea in bright indirect or direct light. It will not thrive if placed in low light.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your Echeveria Rosea when the soil is 100% dry.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Echeveria Rosea does great in average room humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Echeveria Rosea prefers temperatures between 60-90°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your Echeveria Rosea once per season in spring and summer with an all-purpose fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Echeveria are considered to be non-toxic.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Over time, your Echeveria will shed its lower leaves. Though this can be alarming, it is completely natural and does not mean your plant is dying.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your plant will need plenty of bright light to bloom. It will do best by a sunny south or west window.

Title: WATER
Description: Allow the Flowering Kalanchoe’s soil to become 100% dry between waterings. Be careful not to overwater as their roots are prone to root rot. Water slowly, allowing it to soak into the soil, until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot. Discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Flowering Kalanchoe plants do not need high humidity to thrive. These plants will do well in average household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your plant will thrive in rooms with temperatures between 55-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed your plant with a well-balanced fertilizer about once per month during the spring and summer months.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Flowering Kalanchoe plants are considered to be toxic to pets.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: To help the Flowering Kalanchoe rebloom, place it in complete darkness at night for 12-14 hours (closets work best) and then bright light for 10-12 hours. Also, pinch back or cut dead flowers to encourage more blooms.

Water thoroughly so the roots have a chance to soak up the moisture. Make sure there is no standing water left in the saucer, as this can lead to root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Gasteria will do just fine in average room temperatures between 60-80 degrees.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Gasteria will do just fine in average room temperatures between 60-80 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: We suggest fertilizing once in the spring and once in the summer with a succulent fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your Liliputana is non-toxic according to the ASPCA.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Over time, your succulent will shed its lower leaves. Though this can be alarming, it is completely natural and does not mean your plant is dying.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Lace Aloe needs bright direct light. This means a spot that gets 6 plus hours of direct sun per day. If you don’t have a location with ideal lighting for your plant, use aGrow Light!

Title: WATER
Description: Wateryour Lace Aloe when the soil volume is 100% dry. Water thoroughly until it flows out of the drainage hole. Discard excess water to discourage root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: This plant does not require any extra humidity and can handle dry air.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Aloe will appreciate temperatures between 60-90°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Fertilize once per season with acactus or succulent fertilizer.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If physically damaged this plant will ooze a white milky sap. This is normal but can cause skin irritations if it makes skin contact. Be sure to wear gloves when handling.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your Life Saver Cactus needs bright direct light. This means a spot that gets 6 plus hours of direct sun per day.

Title: WATER

Title: TEMPERATURE

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: Take care to use gloves when repotting or handling Madagascar Palm as its spikes can cause pricks.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your silver squill will prefer indirect bright light. Too much light will scorch the leaves.

Title: WATER
Description: Water only when 100% of the soil volume is dry. This succulent-like plant does not tolerate soggy soil. Always water thoroughly and discard any excess water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your silver squill does fine in household humidity.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your silver squill prefers temperatures between 65-85°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed monthly during spring and summer with a general-purpose fertilizer at half strength. Always fertilize on damp soil. No fertilizer is needed in the fall and winter.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: This plant is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: It’s normal for older leaves to yellow as the plant matures and puts energy into new growth. You can remove yellowed leaves with clean, sharp snips. If left on the plant, they will not harm the plant and will eventually fall off on their own.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your String of Bananas in a sunny spot. It will thrive in direct sunlight, but will not tolerate being permanently placed away from a window. At least 4-6 hours of sun is ideal.

Title: WATER
Description: Allow the soil to completely dry out between waterings. When dry, water thoroughly until you see water flow from the drainage hole. Succulents do not like to have ‘wet feet,’ so make sure there is no standing water in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your String of Bananas does not require any extra humidity and can handle dry air.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your String of Bananas will do just fine in normal room temperatures, between 60-90°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for succulents.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your String of Bananas is considered toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If the top of your plant starts to look bare, this most likely means that it is not getting enough light. To make it full again, move it to a sunnier location, lay a couple of strands on top of the soil and pin down using garden pins. These strands will root and make the plant appear full again.

Title: LIGHT

Title: WATER

Title: LIGHT
Description: Your String of Hearts will thrive if it receives bright indirect sunlight, or partial direct sunlight. It can tolerate and will enjoy a few hours of direct sunlight, but don’t place it in full sunlight.

Title: WATER
Description: Water your String of Hearts only when the soil is completely dry. Water until liquid flows through the drainage hole at the bottom of the pot and discard any water that has accumulated in the saucer.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your String of Hearts will do fine in average room humidity, but appreciates extra humidity from a humidifier.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your String of Hearts will do just fine in normal room temperatures, between 65–75 degrees.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once every month during the spring and summer with a liquid fertilizer for succulents.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: Your String of Hearts is considered to be non-toxic.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: If the top of your plant starts to look bare, this most likely means that it is not getting enough light. To make it full again, move it to a sunnier location, lay a couple of strands on top of the soil and pin down using garden pins. These strands will root and make the plant appear full again.

Title: LIGHT
Description: Place your Panda Plant in bright light or full sun. It will not thrive if it does not receive enough sunlight.

Title: WATER
Description: Your Panda Plant does not need to be watered as frequently as most indoor plants.Water your plantonly when the soil is completely dry, or when you notice the leaves starting to shrivel. Water thoroughly so the roots have a chance to soak up the moisture. Make sure there is no standing water left in the saucer, as this can lead to root rot.

Title: HUMIDITY
Description: Your Panda Plant prefers a dry environment. Do not mist, as water droplets can become trapped on the fuzzy surface and lead to fungal issues.

Title: TEMPERATURE
Description: Your Panda Plant will do just fine in average room temperatures between 60-80°F.

Title: FOOD
Description: Feed once in the spring and once in the summer with afertilizer formulated for cacti. Do not fertilize in the fall or winter months when growth naturally slows. Always fertilize on moist soil, never dry, as it can burn the roots.

Title: TOXICITY
Description: These plants are toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

Title: ADDITIONAL CARE
Description: This plant is easily propagated by leaf cuttings. Simply cut off a leaf with cleanplant snips, let the bottom of the cutting callus over for a few days to a week, then plant it in well-draining soil and water only when dry.
